they will reimburse you for all of it - up to 3 meals and 3 snacks a day if you're open, say, 18 to 24 hours. So, you need at least a temporary license.

Are there any additional licensing requirements?

Yeah - another thing you have to do to get a license is have everybody who works at the center fill out a health form verifying a physical examination. The children have to have them, too. They really just want the forms sent in.

Also fire regulations - the fire marshal has to come out and inspect the building. The board of health has to inspect it too.

So after you shell out all the bucks and get an approval you send them into the daycare branch of the State Social Services. Meanwhile the regional daycare consultant is coming around to your center every now and then to look it over and report back to the state about whether or not you should be licensed. The consultant here, Pat Huxol, was the one who "recommended" that the centers were not "operating legally" because of the two-year olds. I think it was partly her responsibility that that hassle came down in the first place -- but in a lot of ways she tried to help us. She pointed out different places and ways to get things and money that we needed. She told us about Operation Mainstream and the Neighborhood Youth Corps. Those are different federal gov't projects providing jobs for low-income people of different ages. People eligible for the different projects can be employed in different community things, like daycare, and get their salary paid by the gov't. So, if you need the help, you can get staff people for the center. We've had people get those kinds of jobs doing the hot lunch program work. I think those things should be ripped off as much as possible. Those jobs should be falsified and the people should be getting the money -- regardless of what kind of work (if any) that they're actually doing.

Where do requirements for licensing come from?

The federal gov't sets up a 17 page booklet of requirements for daycare centers and the state expounds on it and makes it a little tighter. The federal ones are pretty vague and are used as an outline by the state. One of the newest ones is "parental involvement," and they require that the parents be involved in the daycare center -- this is the hip thing of the year. There are all kinds of spacial requirements, etc. too. Like the federal standard will say "adequate indoor and outdoor space for children appropriate to their ages - with separate rooms or areas for cooking, toilets and other purposes ... floors and walls that can be fully cleaned, etc." And the state takes them and makes real picky specifications in about square feet per child, etc. So, if you meet state standards you meet federal ones.

Who administers hot lunch programs?

Hot lunch projects come under the State Department of Public Instruction. Information can be gotten from them. Over that is the Federal Dept. of Agriculture -- and that's where the money comes from. It's matched 75% from Agriculture and 25% from the State Dept. Hot lunch doesn't have to be administered for every particular child. The center has to meet licensing standards, etc. They want to know the economic background of all the people in the center. We can be pretty up front about it since we're trying to serve low income people -- but some of the centers have university people like students and professors and they still get hot lunch money.

How do you get matching funds for donations?

This is for within the state. Say if the Student Senate from the University gives us money they have to set up an ongoing contract with the county board of supervisors and it's just a lot of red tape. Another way to get money is if any ADC parents are in the center and are employed or go to school, especially women on the WIN Program, they can get $75 a month to pay for childcare -- but it's a lot more hassle and shit work for the women on ADC.

What is the WIN Program?

Work Incentive Program for women on welfare to go to school and get a job to get off welfare. I think it's best for women on welfare to just get that daycare money for themselves.

Anything else on licensing?

Yes -- you have to get incorporated. It's a legal thing that any lawyer can tell you how to do and it costs about $20. It just involves a bunch of bullshit -- you have to write out by-laws and articles of incorporation.

Some of the new proposals for standards require at least 6 staff members -- "the nursery's childcare staff and teachers shall have a knowledge of child development and behavior and have the ability to give the children a feeling of security and comfort under the supervision of the executive or operator, be responsible for the guidance and direct childcare." We just got forms at the new daycare center for the workers to fill out. They're part medical and part of them are for the volunteer's work experience with children (and just work experience.) I think that's how they're trying to decide if people are "qualified" and have that "knowledge" of child development. Each center is supposed to keep all kinds of forms on all the kids and workers there on file at all times. "Personal Records for the nursery staff will be complete, including medical reports.. No administrative professional or childcare staff member shall be under the age of 16 or over the age of 70." I imagine that the licensing standards vary from state to state.

What we've been trying to do is meet the requirements that we can without too much hassle, and shying on the ones that are too much hassle or cost too much to meet. So far we've kept temporary licenses by doing that. I don't know how long that'll last.

The concept of service has always bothered me  
but maybe I should explain what I mean by ser-  
vice. I mean by service those projects that we  
do for a group of people other than ourselves--  
a group we do not identify with. For instance,  
the class action workshop was a group of women  
who offered transportation to welfare mothers  
to pick up their government surplus food and  
also sent out welfare handbooks to people on  
welfare in this county. None of these women  
were on welfare themselves. Also the Free  
Medical Clinic in Iowa City, and most of the  
daycare centers including Sparky where you and  
I work.  

There are two things I really believe in--  
one is that people needing a service should  
have control over the service they receive, the  
other that people should have control over  
their own labor. Since the workers and users  
of a service are rarely the same people, it  
seems to me that someone ends up being screw-  
ed. Usually I think it is the people most in  
need of the service that suffer at the hands  
of those offering the service who normally  
have no gut understanding of the need. But  
there are so many complexities to the issue of  
daycare and in the past I think volunteers  
and workers at daycare centers have been  
forced to hide or give up their feminist poli-  
tics in order to supply service to people who  
did not accept them, to work in situations  
that were offensive to them; to find it imposs-  
ible to relate to children in any honest way.  

What you say about service is substantiated  
by my experiences. As you know, I was in the  
class action workshop and have had a lot of  
time to observe the Free Medical Clinic be-  
cause I work there.  

My reason for involving myself in class  
action workshop was that I wanted to work on  
something that had tangible results. The only  
real tangible result of that was that I felt  
that I was doing something. Is that clear?  
What I'm trying to say is that service pro-  
jects often make the do-gooder feel good. Not  
a very good reason for existence.  

The Free Medical Clinic speaks for itself.  
It serves no one but the doctors who assuage  
their guilt on the patients. The Women's  
Clinic was different, I felt, because the wo-  
men involved had a stake in the clinic because  
we needed it and had some control of it. And  
when we found that we would lose that control  
by altering its structure (by using male doc-  
tors because the female doctors would not sup-  
port us) we closed it down because it was no  
longer useful to us. That seems correct to  
me.  

Which brings me to Sparky. I don't even  
think of it in terms of being a service pro-  
ject, for two reasons. First, it meets the

In a daycare center you need furniture  
and playthings that cost a lot of money.  

One way around that is to build as much  
stuff as you can yourself.  

Wood is expensive, but lumber yards will  
always let you raid their scrap pile. They  
might even give you some wood if you say  
it's for a daycare center, but we haven't  
had luck with this. For heavier lumber  
like 4x4's and 2x4's go to a construction  
site and ask if they have any old or short  
pieces. Heavy construction sites like  
high rises or poured concrete buildings  
even though there's not a stick in them  
still use lumber for forms, scaffolding and  
supports. A poured concrete building in  
the process of being built will have a  
whole shit load of 4x4's to get rid of.  

Lumber is named for what it measures before  
it is finished and dried.  

The measurements of our lumber was 3/4"  
by 11 1/4". First, cut the 5 pieces you  
need:  

top--12 1/4"x11 1/4"  
2 sides--11 1/4"x11 1/4"  
2 sides--10 3/4"x11 1/4"  

Then nail the top and the two square sides  
together. When you nail to a board on end  
like this make sure there is a sturdy surf-  
ace beneath the upright piece or else some  
of your effort is wasted. Use something  

of similar height to prop up the other end  
of the horizontal piece. Don't fight it.  

Next weekend we are going to begin build-  
ing the SUPER PLAYTHING. We designed it by  
gathering ideas from Big Rock Candy Moun-  
tain (published 6 times/yr by Portola  
Institute Inc., 1115 Merrill St., Menlo  
Park, Calif. 94025) and by trying to in-  
clude in it as many motor developing things  
as possible. We hope it will help the kids  
mature physically, become stronger and give  
them something to organize their playing  
around so we won't always have to be stop-  
ping fights and destruction.  

We were lucky obtaining material. We got  
the 4x4's from a heavy construction site,  
the 2x4's we found in a garage, and the  
1x2's and plywood we scavenged from houses  
the city is tearing down because of urban  
renewal. When working with lumber this  
thick that must have square ends, you  
should probably borrow a power saw. It's  
not that the wood is that hard to saw by  
hand, but your body naturally slants the saw  
one way or the other. When sawing through  
3 1/2" of wood you may get a difference of  
1/2" between one side and the other.

Somehow analyze the structure of dissension....

One lesson well learned through childcare hassles is that the only produc-
tive confrontation is in groups and in person. (That's not to say learning
doesn't go on in other ways than by confrontation.) Confrontations have
to do with politics and politics are never simple. Talking one-to-one
after a confrontation tends to so simplify the politics because no one
person can represent the variety of struggles in a group. So no headway
is made, issues are muddied, and everyone hears 2nd or 5th hand what's
been said--open range for gossip and backbiting.

among ourselves

One-to-one talking, like working out your politics alone and outside of
any collective has the disadvantages of (1) not representing the variety
of struggles in a group; (2) of not allowing the people involved to hear
the different ways a certain event in time has been perceived (factual
clarity). Collective or public talking's disadvantage of possibly not
exposing all those varieties of political struggle and fact perception
--because of the time limits, shyness or intimidation individuals may feel--
can be rectified by careful attention to the matter of hearing everyone.
Whereas, when only 2 people speak to each other -- no amount of trying to
consider other points of view, life situations, can adequately represent them
if those who experience them are absent. The need for collective and public
group struggle is clear, but we must do it in a context which does not
exclude women with less time (because of work and/or children) from partici-
pating--one of the main failings of the women's community in Iowa City.

One of the big problems is having to speak with a loud, urgent voice in
order to be heard. We've all learned that in order to get people to under-
stand and/or deal with our oppressions, we have to first convince them we
have a voice at all. So when you have to be loud and dramatic and overcome
your being used to never having a voice, not everything comes out the way
you'd want it to. Not to mention the anger. I don't see any way around
that. And people who get blown over a little by such voices should be
aware of why and give space to the women speaking. (Unless, of course,
their own space is being totally confiscated by the women speaking.

(continued)

Unless these women say things that are so blatantly racist, classist,
sexist or homosexist that it threatens whatever space other women have
for themselves.) If we only hear the "incorrect" thinking the oppressed
are doing, we never hear their oppression.

Postscript: Dissension with a genuine attitude of struggle (oppressed people strug-
gling together to unite without oppressing each other) is not destructive.

What is destructive is anything which prevents or inhibits that struggle,
including assuming that the other is either unwilling or unable either
to listen or to change and taking part of the facts or issue for the
whole (by listening to gossip instead of verifying the facts, by isolating
oneself from others while making judgments and/or taking actions which
affect them).

On this issue in this community-- up until very recently--these wrong
practices have been the rule rather than the exception. That is beginning
to change now and already the benefits are beginning to show. In the most
recent daycare meeting there was some indication on many sides for willing-
ness to struggle.

a lesbian mother

Here are a few viewpoints on childcare, based on my experience
as the lesbian mother of a four year old girl.

1. Female children need care from dykes, starting from an early
age. Development of a child's sexuality and body image starts at
infancy, and is much influenced by her physical contact with
adults. In the nuclear family, a woman has the status of an object,
not an autonomous being and her body communicates this concept of
femaleness to her daughter. The child is taught to be passive,
feminine, and heterosexual before she reaches school.

A dyke is a better mother than a straight woman in that respect,
because a dyke's concept of herself and other women offers the
child much more space for the growth and development of aggressiveness,
initiative, self-confidence and other dykey qualities.

2. Male supremacy is very uptight about lesbians raising girls;
we threaten them. The courts view a lesbian mother as an unwholesome
influence on a child, similar to an alcoholic or a prostitute. So a lesbian
stands a small chance of keeping custody of her child if her ex-husband,
family, or any male institution takes the slightest interest in removing
the child. The threat can be used to force a lesbian to raise her daughter
“normally” -- that is, to meet male approval. Some women have been driven
to desperate lengths to keep their children, such as changing their names
and moving out of state.

3. A female child needs good quality care from several women to
develop a strong sense of self-worth and independence from her
mother. It's real weird for a child to feel that one person cares
intensely for her and no one else gives a shit. She wonders what
would happen to her if her mother disappeared, and why no one else
bothers with her much. A child who regularly gets positive feedback
from several directions is much less easily defeated by a blast of negative
energy than is a child who is totally dependent on her mother.

A WOMAN?

4. Mother's commitment to her child.

There is, I believe, an element of choice in motherhood (although I did not
"choose" to be oppressed and the choice I made does not justify my oppression),
and that is that any mother can choose at any time to abandon her child. A year ago, I did abandon my daughter to the care of her father. I was working and living alone with her and constantly fatigued; I knew no women who would do childcare for me (her?). So he took custody of her and she got real messed up. After much soul searching, I realized that I had to try to regain custody of her; I felt that no political involvement could be more meaningful or productive than caring for her. But then I hit the lesbian-mother stumbling block; my chances in court were poor, according to several lawyers. So finally I had to disappear with her. The alternative was to abandon her to the mutilation of a "straight" upbringing -- Barbie dolls, makeup, skirts, kissing up to "Daddy."

In response to the “old gay" view that children are products of hetero relationships and so no responsibility of gay women:

No other woman would do this for her. I regard my decision to care for my daughter as a lesbian-feminist commitment. She is not a leftover from a heterosexual relationship; she is a four year old woman, as worthy of my time and energy (and anyone's) as any other woman.

5. Males are unfit to care for female children.

6. I will take no responsibility for the care of male children,
and question the motives of women who do take that responsibility.

Teri is a three-year-old child who was  
living with her biological mother in a  
collective situation that was intolerable  
for her: while her mother was happy there,  
Teri was not compatible with the other  
people in the collective. She needed an-  
other place to live and someone else to  
live with.  

The time it took to evolve a solution  
for Teri illustrates some things we are  
gradually becoming more conscious of: that  
“children are people who have individual  
personalities, and that all adults do not  
get along with all children (or vice versa)  
any more than they get along with all  
other adults. That children are entirely  
dependent on adults for a long time makes  
it more difficult to deal with personality  
conflicts as such: you can't just stay  
away from a child you are responsible for.  
You could get someone else to take respon-  
sibility for the child, but there are two  
things that make it real hard. The main  
one, of course, is that no one is into  
giving up as much of her self-determination  
as taking care of a child requires. The  
other thing is that the mystique of mother-  
hood still haunts us and no biological  
mother is supposed to not like her child.  
Even as people give voice to the oppression  
of mothers and try to take "their share"  
of responsibility and hassle for the chil-  
dren we have, they are shocked and not  
understanding of mothers who could want to  
escape this hassle when hassle is all it is.  

Anyway, after much thinking and talking  
and hassle among adults, a group of people  
became "mother" to Teri, taking complete  
responsibility for her. We are a group of  
eight women. All of us are gay. Five of  
us are working-class, three are middle-  
class. We all knew each other, previous  
to coming together in this group, through  
the political and social functioning of  
the women's community here. Some of us  
merely knew each other, some are good  
friends, some are lovers. We came together  
at our first meeting not knowing who would  
be there -- that meeting that finally  
happened after Teri's mother came to us  
and declared her desperation -- but we  
found that it was a reasonable number of  
people (in fact an amazingly large number  
considering how much more this is than a  
commitment to daycare) and that we all  
felt we could work together. We have basic  
agreements in theory on things like good  
foods being important for children, teach-  
ing her to be strong and independent,  
teaching her to be a dyke not a lady,  
teaching her that her mind and body are  
integral and that her sexuality is part of  
that whole, etc. We want her to learn  
these things through secure but non-depen-  
dent relationships with many people which  
we think can be formed by the structure  
that we have since set up for her.

Actually, that structure was real simple  
and easy. We had a meeting, and there were  
eight of us, so we could each take respon-  
sibility for one day a week (with a double-  
up), just once a week, and we each put in  
$2 a month into expenses, that's not too  
much... We constructed a bedroom for her in  
the basement of the living collective of  
two in our group and moved her into the  
daycare center where we all work. In order  

for the adults to communicate across this  

structure, we have a logbook that accompa-  
nies Teri and her toothbrush wherever they  
go, and scheduled meetings twice a month to  
talk about things. And it all seems cool  

and easy...  

...except that Teri is a complicated  
and needful person whose needs are much  
more than just those present material ones  

that are so easily filled. We have become  
the people who are totally responsible for  
Teri's mental and emotional well-being as  
well. That is real frightening. It depends  
on us whether she is happy, whether she  
feels loved and how dependent she is. And  
it is even more frightening to have this  
responsibility and to be trying to fulfill  
it by creating a totally new structure.  

We have an analysis of what we are doing:  
it is unnecessary, if not damaging, for a  
child (or any person) to be dependent on  
one person; the structure of mono-relating  
is conducive to the development of jealousy  
and possessiveness, which are destructive.  
Living with eight people who are all equally  
responsible to her, Teri will see many  
points of view and ways of dealing with  
things as valid, rather than just one or  
two. She will be with each adult for  
short enough periods of time that that time  
can be enjoyable and not oppressive for  
either of them in terms of resentment and  
hostility over constant demands, or constant  
dependency, or just constant togetherness.  
And because her "mothers" do not all live  
in the same house, and have various affil-  
iations throughout the women's community,  

the situation is in a sense community,  
rather than individual, responsibility  

to her. So, we decided she would live in  
one place four days a week and that would  
be her home, a base of security for her,  
and that other days she would visit at  
other people's houses and relate to a dif-  
ferent person each day and that will be a  
really good way for her to live.  

But how do we know? Our well-thought-  
out analysis is just that: ideas. What we  
are doing has never been tried extensively.  
No one is experienced in raising a child  
until she does it, but the way we are doing  
it has not even poor tradition to back it  
up. And much as we may believe in it, it  
is an experiment whose subject is a little  
girl whose entire life is dependent on us...  
and whom we love very much. That is why  
it is so frightening.  

And we have not worked everything out  
yet even as far as practicalities go.  
Raising a child is a long-term thing and  
people have not stated specifically that  
they plan to stay in Iowa City until she  
grows up. Since it is unlikely that our  
whole group will move, going to something  
else would mean leaving Teri. Money will  
be a bigger problem as she gets older than  
it is now. What will be the legal hassles:  
will one of us have to become her owner,  
i.e., adopt her, in order for all of us to  
take care of her? What will happen if  
there are splits within the group? Because  
it is so intensely difficult to set up such  
a new structure in this society, taking  
responsibility for Teri is made even  
more frightening.  

My perspective on writing this is that  
for several months before our group formed,  
while Teri still lived in her mother's  
collective, I had been taking care of  
Teri two nights a week. Only one other  
woman in the group was relating to her on  
any regular basis at all, although we all  
knew her to differing degrees. Now Teri  
lives in my collective, her room is right  
next to mine, she shares my bathroom and  
we are just generally thrown together a  
lot. Teri knows me better than she knows  
any of the other women, she has felt closer  
to me in some ways and more secure with me,  
and this manifests itself at times in a  
kind of clinging dependency on me that is  
a source of worry and some annoyance with-  
in our group. I have been criticized for  

perhaps not discouraging this dependency  
enough. The consensus of the group now  
seems to be, however, that it is more a  
function of our prior relationship than a  
growing unhealthy relationship now, that  
it is good that she feels close to one of  
us, and that eventually she will feel as  
close to all of us.  

Teri is happier now than she was when  
she lived with her mother's collective --  
she is more sociable and more secure. She  
has been calling our collective "my house"  
and seems to have relaxed into knowing we  
are going to be there. It seems as if for  
now our ideas are working out in practice.  
And so now we can look ahead...at the  
next 15 years.  

Charity G

You are right about privilege in relation to working-lower class women. We are not privileged in any sense that middle class women are, and our politics and working with middle class women doesn't change that position. I know that in ten years my politics will not have changed the way I live. I was saying, however, that our politics puts us in contact with Sparky—because of that position we have primary access to it. I think my being pissed off at what I saw happening at Sparky made that somewhat unclear.

My main concern is to provide childcare for women and children on as widespread a basis as possible. Lower-working class women have the least access to childcare. In my mind, these people come first. Children who have other options and more chance to be in childcare are not my concern. It makes no difference that Teri's group has more or as many working class women as middle class women. First, she has exposure to alternate childcare situations—and second, a seven adult to one child ratio doesn't rate anywhere near the need as a one adult (mother) to one child (or more) ratio.

You say you "got tremendously pissed at my desire to serve lower and working class women you don't yet know, when you refused to hear what lower and working class women, who you do know, wanted." There are a couple of points I want to make about that. First, I don't want to serve working-lower class women. "Serving" people is romantic bullshit used by privileged groups to relieve their guilt or add a little spice to their lives. As a working class mother, I don't want your service because that means you doing it on your terms. It's like if I hear one more middle class woman say, "Lower class people don't want charity"—I think I'll scream. You're damn right we don't want your charity—all those conditions and strings. Charity and service only are good for those dispensing it—ego trips. A good example of "service" or "charity" is what happened with Teri—no one would take her because they were supposed to—it was done to "save" her (social work attitude). But we do want you to do what you're supposed to do—in this case provide childcare because you have extra resources (from being childless). That means do it not because you want to for some reason but because you're supposed to. You have no right to hoard extra resources. In this society, there's no name for that kind of giving but it's not "service" or "charity." It sounds real nice to say people should serve themselves first—it doesn't have much basis in reality, however, if you're a mother—and no basis at all if you're a lower-working class person and mother. What resources do these groups of people have to serve themselves?

A second point I want to make about your statement is about the point that I have refused to hear what lower-working class women I know want. You are wrong—that is all I have heard and I'm sick of it. Mothers have been systematically shut out of Sparky and any community dealings with motherhood. "Those women don't have time to come to meetings and anyway they'd freak out. They shouldn't be here." I want non-mothers to quit making decisions for mothers. The working-lower class non-mothers involved in Sparky fuck me over just as much as middle class non-mothers with their childless options. Which brings me to the point about who should have control over major decisions at Sparky.

I want to point out that we do not live in a revolutionary society. Almost every child at Sparky goes home to her mother every night and ten years from now that's where that child will still be. How childless women who have no concept of what childcare involves can presume to make decisions that affect those mothers is beyond me. And everything that happens in that center affects those mothers' lives—it doesn't work out that what happens in daycare and what happens at home are two separate entities. There are all kinds of carryovers from one to the other. At this point, mothers have no reason to trust non-mothers no matter how much childcare that non-mother has done. First, the childcare that non-mothers do is so minimal and on top of that it is pretty damn atrocious. I don't know any non-mother who does childcare that doesn't do things to or with the children involved that doesn't increase the burden on the mother when the child returns. Of course, childless persons can afford to do this since they don't have to deal with the mess later (i.e., not giving children naps who need them, feeding them crap instead of balanced food, being careless with safety measures). Then there are the guilt trips laid on mothers by non-mothers. Childless persons who do childcare never have to deal with that—and they are often the ones who lay on the guilt. I could go on and on about why mothers have no reason to trust you.

It is misleading for childless persons who do childcare to call themselves non-biological mothers—the implication is that although biologically you are not mothers, in practice you are. You never will be because you'll never have to experience what mothers must—nor do I think you should have to—but non-biological mother implies that the person has struggled with her oppressiveness and come to a realization of what a mother's oppression is. No childless woman in this community has struggled. Childless women are reinforcing each other's oppressiveness and fuck-ups. You are defining how you oppress mothers and not listening to what mothers say. When you do struggle and mothers have reason to trust you, then control of major decisions should be yours too. But it is up to the mothers to define when that oppression has stopped. It's a long way off as far as I can see.

You have consistently ignored my motherhood in your criticisms. You talk rather glibly about my "hustling supports from middle class women." You can't see that my life and needs are not the same as yours precisely because of my motherhood. I am in the rather uncomfortable position of having to choose between: 1) living/dealing with lower-working class mothers and being oppressed because of my gayness and politics, 2) living/dealing with lower-working class, feminist, gay non-mothers and being oppressed because of my motherhood, 3) living/dealing with middle class mothers and being oppressed because of my class, or 4) living alone. Obviously, number one is out for several reasons (it is near impossible to live with only mothers with no help from non-mothers), two is out because I have yet to find a childless person of any class who wants to deal with children. Mothers already burdened with childcare are always the first and often the only ones to help out with children. I will never live alone with a child again if I can help it. The only alternative that has worked out in my life is living with a middle class mother and another woman who is middle class and dealing with childcare. It's not so easy as a pick and choose situation—when you have children it leaves you no room to be fussy. You must take what you can get. You cannot even see through to my oppression as a mother.

You can choose to ignore my needs and the needs of all mothers. And the structure is such in this community (as well as in society at large) that mothers have no power—because you have all the options to pull out anytime you wish. Mothers can do nothing without childcare. You talk about the money from our collective coming out of bounty with strings attached. Don't forget the threat you hold over every mother's head because of the bounty of energy that comes from your being childless and that you can put or not put into childcare as you choose. Mothers haven't forgotten it—it's been used on them too much.

One more thing—I'm sick of non-mothers telling me how I should think. "The reason she wants this or that is because she still wants control over the child. After all, she's a mother and mothers are possessive. Not that they don't have reasons to be possessive..., etc." If I say I don't feel like that you say or assume I'm lying and don't want to admit how I really feel. I can't have a valid reason for anything—I'm a mother. What it comes down to is my real reasons don't fit your plans.

As I was putting this together, it occurred to me this is a waste of time because everyone always says, "Well, she's not talking about me. I'm struggling really hard. How can she say that?"

I want to make it clear that I do mean you—no exceptions exist in this community.

I think of material resources. It's especially when resources are low that you must serve yourself first. When you talk about correctly serving working-class mothers I assume you are talking about your own needs. That's what I mean about serving yourself first.

#4 Saying you're sick of hearing from other working and lower class women who have been making criticisms about class and homophobia is a drag. Homophobia has been making me sick all my life. Speaking about this community alone, I am sure that in 10 or 15 years queers will be oppressed in the same ways that children will go home from daycare to their mothers. In 10 or 15 years we're liable to have 24-hour daycare and mothers will be able to go on to something else, like choosing to be gay when it's convenient and choosing not to exercise a gay consciousness when it's not convenient.

#5 Heterosexual mothers and gay mothers know nothing about what affects my life and they don't much care unless, as Mary said, it is affecting or will affect the quality of the childcare they're getting. It would be nice not to make any decisions that affected mothers. It would probably be nice if mothers didn't make any decisions that affected my life. Since that's not the reality, the decisions at Sparky must be joint. Mothers, by the way, have not been "systematically excluded" from Sparky. There were mothers at every meeting, more at the most recent meeting than at any other. If your comment comes out of paranoia you might notice that the lesbians keep expecting to be thrown out, etc. as in the past. That is another reason for joint decisions. Trust cuts both ways.

There have been public struggles over mistakes and disagreements, but I wish you would clarify because it is a very serious charge. The a.m. naps (when I am there) are regular.

A child I know told an adult that she was going to “bite her  
all over." The adult later smiled at the image of hoards of child-  
ren attacking adults biting them all over their bodies. This idea  
is amazingly similar to the actions of women, united against their  
oppressors, during the Chinese revolution. I do not think the  
comparison should be taken lightly.  

Children have little or no control over money, transportation,  
their living situation, their time or energy, even their anger is  
laughed at, ignored or beat out of them. A child says something  
that is perfectly serious and is laughed at for being cute, then  
catching on, she or he tries to do it again for a laugh and is  
rebuffed. Adults talk about children as though they were little  
animals who aren't quietly hearing every word. And women who  
would like to bash in the face of men who call them chicks (baby  
chickens) continue referring to children as kids (baby goats), and  
on and on.  

Being unable to physically survive alone, children are totally  
subject to the adults that take care of them. This dependency  
falls largely on mothers who are fed large doses of mystification  
and guilt (along with who knows what else) to get them into their  
roles and keep them there in order to provide the necessary labor.  
At the same time a mother and child begin to know each other and  
special feelings build up like with a person you've been friends  
with since grade school. Generally, though, the mother has total  
responsibility for and control of the child. The mother is  
oppressed by the institution of motherhood which takes so much  
time and energy that she begins to lose herself, becoming "Mary's  
mother" and frequently someone's wife as well, but never a person  
in her own right. In anger and frustration she hits, pleads,  
screams, and punishes the child so she or he will be good enough  
to be worth the mother's life, and also so that the child will  
leave her alone, get off her back. The child responds to this  
overt oppression by trying to "be good" though she or he can  
never quite make it, by anger/screaming, crying, fighting, and by  
sneaking around to get what she or he wants. Children usually  
learn pretty fast how much or how little power they actually  
have, when to shuffle, how to get by and do the best they can, etc.  

Children are oppressed by adults and at the same time are  
used as instruments for the oppression of mothers. What should  
be a very nice friendship turns into a complicated love/hate mess.  

Many adults are beginning to relate to their passive oppres-  
sion of mothers in allowing this to happen and are doing child-  
care as one approach to changing the institution which oppresses  
mothers (and by association all women). And they are now being  
confronted with their oppression of children. Some women freak  
out when they realize that they are doing to children what has  
been done to them, they are the enemy too. Others simply dig  
in and begin to try to change things. All make mistakes.  

The first reaction is usually total permissiveness, a des-  
perate illogical fear of doing something oppressive leads to  
allowing and sometimes even encouraging children to pick up adults'  
worst habits. Children are allowed to smoke and drink beer  
(children have small livers which can't deal with these things  
very well), regulate all their own sleeping and eating habits,  
and destroy everything in sight. Coughing, sickly, grouchy,  
obnoxious tyrants begin making enormous demands on shocked adults  
who forget that children don't have all the information and exper-  
ience necessary to make many decisions, and they sometimes go

The state many adults seem to be in now may be a reaction  
to this or may simply be another approach but it seems to be a  
pretty widespread situation. Having total control, many adults  
now seem to be struggling with the problem of the oppression  
of children with a different form of adult chauvinism: the child  
as a political experiment rather than a person, with the adult  
political ideology imposed on the child, not by example but by  
force: emotional and/or physical. Girls, for example, should not  
wear dresses, sounds familiar in reverse. With male children this  
sort of thing is just as devastating. The female is told it's  
good to be tough and strong and to fight for her rights “don't  
be wimpy". He, in the next sentence, is told to be wimpy, be  
passive, wear dresses, be quiet and submissive. If she hits him  
she's applauded, if he pushes her down he's a bully. But all of  
this totally disregards two real people struggling to live togeth-  
er: fairness is often neglected in favor of a political abstrac-  
tion.  

School and television and the whole rest of the world is  
telling the male to be macho and the female to be wimpy, but  
just telling them and trying to enforce the opposite isn't  
working. She wants people to know she's a girl, she's proud of  
being female. And people rebel against being taught to be weak  
so he's lost, ignored if he's passive, rejected if he's aggressive.  
Those are the only two alternatives that we have so far been able  
to give them.  

Children don't seem to identify with our ideals, they iden-  
tify with us. They don't have all the information necessary to  
sort out the good from the bad. A friend of mine who is almost  
four years old lives with people who don't smoke. One night  
I noticed that she was picking up my cigarette butts and trying  
to smoke them, all the time I was explaining how smoking is bad  
for you. Adults need to be giving fewer criticisms to children  
and more to themselves—and each other.  

It seems necessary that all children be given love and re-  
spect and space to grow equal to their repression as a severely  
oppressed class of people. With male children this is amazingly  
difficult, perhaps because there are so many privileges attached  
to traditional male behavior and so few men who are decent models.  
For male children living within a gay women's community this can  
become especially difficult. If a male child constantly hears  
that all males are hated he will learn not only to hate himself  
but also the people who taught him. If he is constantly rejected  
simply for being male he will see no reason to struggle, or to  
try to be different. There are a few adult males who have shown  
by virtue of consistently assuming responsibility for children  
over extended periods of time that they are sincere. It seems  
that we must begin to judge their efforts with the same degree of  
trust that we hope for from children and other people that we our-  
selves oppress, putting faith in actions rather than words. Male  
children sometimes choose to relate to male adults and feel it is  
unfair that they live with all women and no men. To a gay mother  
this is a frightening problem. A child is not loved more or less  
by a mother because of what sex she or he is but simply as a  
special person with unique needs. Those needs for male children  
are often not met by other gay women except in the most limited  
ways and with some resentment, not liking, for example to be  
touched by male children but enjoying being touched by female  
children. But it seems that we teach children their roles by  
treating them differently rather than treating them as individuals  
within an oppressed class.  

It seems that we must begin to deal with our oppressiveness  
in the ways we've learned and been taught to analyze our oppres-  
sion. We must listen to children. It was a child who told me  
that he didn't like being called a kid, he only told me once. A  
screaming child is trying to say something, we must listen to  
children's anger; not demand explanations when we're criticized;  
try to share our privileges equally with children; remember that  
with children too the inability to articulate does not mean an  
inability to think or to hear and understand. We should allow  
children to spend time alone with each other, safe from eaves-  
dropping adults (although their physical safety must be consider-  
ed too); and encourage and support their unity with each other  
in struggling with their oppressors.  

With these sorts of cross references we can begin to deal  
with such everyday situations as the similarity of an adult  
ripping off a record and a child sneaking a forbidden toy. Child-  
ren cannot write down their feelings to help each other understand  
and unite against their oppression. They are totally at our  
mercy. It seems that learning to use power fairly is something  
never taught in this society, something that women are struggling  
hard to teach themselves. With children this necessity for fair-  
ness is urgent because they learn our oppressiveness as they  
suffer from it. We cannot afford to be any more liberal or less  
critical with ourselves than we are with people we consider to be  

our enemies.

Q: You were around when free daycare got started in Iowa City,  
right? I wasn't into that. Could you tell me how you heard  
about it and how you felt about it?  

A: It's hard to start out with just the free daycare movement.  

The free daycare movement seemed to come out of the other one,  

the movement with University preschools and with cooperative day-  
care, where you could give 8 hours a week and then it's free,  
otherwise it's pro-rated: the amount of money that you paid being  
according to the amount of time that you could put in. It was like  
the national movement of daycare centers, with fairly middle class  
and university women doing a daycare thing, so I guess my first  
impression is like I had of the whole movement -- it was only in-  
clusive for people like those people that started it. It didn't go  
outside the immediate group.  

Q: Could you explain in what ways you are not part of that,  
what your situation is?  

A: My situation is different in a way. Well, I am a student. I  
wasn't always a student, so in the past when daycare started I was  
not only a black woman and an unmarried woman but I was on welfare.  
That gave us a total dichotomy between myself and the people who  
ran and populated daycare centers. So, while I am a student right  
now, that's a real unimportant part of describing me. So I guess I  
would still have a major difference from the rest in being from a  
whole different background and situation from white middle class  
student women.  

Q: So they got theirs started. Did they make any overtures to  
you to get into it or anything? Or did you just know about it?  
A: Well, being black in a white university community, you do  
have a sort of pull from the more radical elements to get in-  
volved. So I was approached by the university people to partici-  
pate, and I'm sure other black women with children here have been  
wooed to participate. Mostly without success because black wo-  
men are not real hipped up on letting highly "political" types  
take care of their children.  

Q: So there was this dichotomy between you and the "hip" univer-  
sity community who were getting this together. And so they told  
you about it? Did they come and say, 'Do you want to do this?'  
or did you kinda just cool it from that or what?  

A: I guess the first people aren't the same people that we would  
be talking about if we talked about the existing Sparky community  
or something like that, because the first group of people -- ad  
hoc committees for dealing with children -- were some of the peo-  
ple who are outside the community that we talk about; but they  
were middle class women, and some of them were married and had  
black children, and I guess that's what the immediate negative  
reaction that came from single black women on campus was dealing  
with -- these people that had black children that were white, because  
it was real hard for black women to trust their kids to people  
that would take a child knowing that they couldn't give them the  
kind of future that they need, the kind of identity and everything,  
and so you aren't going to give your own kids to them to do the  
same things they're going to do to the black kids they adopted.  

So in the very beginning, back in '67, those kinds of people were  
involved in trying to set up daycare. They weren't real success-  
ful but those were the first people that approached black women.  

Q: Would you like to run down your politics about how you feel  
about that?  

A: Well, it's just that, you know, we haven't gotten to the point  
where we're all people yet. I mean, that's ridiculous. That's just  
real superfluous to talk about it even -- White middle class people,  
and even upper class, especially around here, they are professors  
and so start to leave the middle class with those kinds of salar-  
ies. But any white person hard as you might try, it's hard to fig-  
ure out what it's like to be black, and all the empathy in the  
world isn't what you need. And this child grows up and they need  
more blackness than the child in the ghetto because the child in  
the ghetto does at least see other black people. This child is  
going to grow up knowing that everything he sees good in the whole  
world is white and then there's nothing that the parent can tell  
him that's going to change that, because children see what we do  
and how we act and not what we say. So tell them that black people  
are really worthwhile and they don't even see any, you know, it  
just doesn't settle right in their stomachs. It'd be like in the  
early '60s when they said the talk about equality without doing  
anything about it, when you could tell a child that the child next  
to him was equal yet that child couldn't go into the same restau-  
rants or couldn't go to the same schools, had to go to inferior  
everything, I mean to that child the words were meaningless. And  
that's the same thing that happens to black kids that grow up in  
white families is that you can't say enough to take the place of  
what's actually going on in his life -- that he was saved from  
being in an institution by a wonderful white family that sends him

to wonderful white schools to sit by nice little pretty white  
children, and then that parent is going to make some effort to say,  
you know, your difference shouldn't matter -- that right there is  
negative. It's saying even though you're not the same as us you can  
strive to be like us. The whole thing is real messed up. We haven't  
gotten to the point yet that people can take cross-cultural things  
like that. I don't think that's always the case; but it's the case  
when a person from a majority society is taking a minority child.  

I say that there's a difference because if a white child grew up in  
a black family, no matter what he lives in America, and there's  
nothing in the world like being white in America, and nothing you  
could do at home would take the place of what goes on outside in  
the world. He knows he's worthwhile 'cause he goes to school, and  
he sees the president looks just like him, v.p., and the whole damn  
senate, and there's nothing that that black family at home could  
tell that child that that whole world wouldn't erase, so you know,  
it wouldn't be the same always cross-culturally, but it definitely  
is when the child comes from a minority culture.  

Q: So those daycare centers because they were staffed by whites  
were no different from putting your child into a white family?  

A: Right. Definitely. Any daycare center staffed by white people  
would be like putting them in a white family. They cannot meet the  
needs of that child no matter how many of them there are and I see  
that even putting him in a daycare center -- another angle is that  
people ask you to bring your black child so that the white kids can  
get used to being around black children, and I think that's a real  
bunch of shit, because it's like your child isn't really a real  
person, it's a doll, you buy it for the kids to play with.  

Q: Did that actually happen? Can you describe?  

A: Oh, yes. We can start out with welfare. When I started out with  
welfare here in Iowa City, they have their own daycare centers -- well  
people -- you couldn't call them daycare centers -- babysitter centers,  
where one woman or two women takes care of a group of children from  
welfare families, and the welfare pays her. And they approached me  
because I was talking about going back to school, so that I'd have  
child care that wouldn't cost me, and the person that was sitting  
for me then, they couldn't certify her for various reasons, and the  
people that they took me to always came up with the fact that they  
thought it'd be good for the other kids to be around the little black  
child. Or if they were hesitant, they weren't sure what the other  
kids would think having a black child. It was always negative.  

They always came up with they were always happy to have him, but it  
was for the sake of the other children. This was something new and  
it'd be real fun for them. I think that’s real detrimental to  
children to be treated like they're a nonentity, and their only  
worth is in the goodness that they can bring to other people's  
lives. If you decide to do that for yourself that's one thing, but  
for other people to decide that for you, it's real strange. That's  
the way it was with the first Dum Dum and up and down Melrose Ave  
with the preschools. The attitude they took...  

Q: (Interrupting) This was supposedly from the feminist or women's  
community?  

A: Especially the further down Melrose you got like when it got  
down to Dum Dum. They were more radical than, say, Melrose Pre-  
school -- commercially run and has no pretenses to being cooperative.  
I had classes by then with people that worked at them. They were  
teaching assistants and research assistants that had talked to me  
in classes about bringing my child to daycare. Some of the people  
from that center did talk to me and said they thought it'd be good  
to have a black child in there -- the other kids, they could learn  
equality and I don't know what else they were supposed to learn.  

Q: And they'd see to it that the black child learned his lesson  
subtly. (Laughing)  

A: (Laughing) Yeah, that he was there for the service of mankind  
and not there for his own... you know, he had nothing to do with  
himself being there. He was there to be played with. Which is, I  
don't know, real strange. In those terms they would be totally  
abhorred and that's not what they had in mind. “How do our children  
learn if they're not around them?" They learn to be racist without  
being around them, so I imagine they could probably teach 'em other  
things, too.  

Q: You're part of the community of women, made up of gay women in  
town who have for political reasons broken with those other daycare  
centers and formed another one, and yet we're still this white day-  
care center. Can you talk about how you feel about that?  

A: Well, I mean that's true, it is a white daycare center so I  
think that on a personal level -- while myself and other women that  
I know that have talked about daycare and the people that run that  
daycare center, you know, we can deal with them on a personal and  
adult level because at this point we pretty much know where we're  
at as third world women. There isn't a lot of harm that can be done.

to our psyches by them. And if I and my other friends felt it hap-

pening we'd leave; I mean, we know the difference. A child would
not. He'd be subjected to that and if we weren't around we would
not know what was happening to him in that center. People can't
help being white and being the kind of people they are. I'm not
saying that people are just mean and like driving black children
nuts, but the job gets done and intentions aren't nearly as import-
ant as the effect they're having on the children. And to have that
many--especially that place where you have 15 adults around a lot--
that many white people supervising black children--I think it'd be
bad. It's bad enough black children end up inevitably having to go
to school and having white teachers and start to get that later. I
guess we can put it off as long as we can--having white supervision.
Hopefully, we can send 'em to a school where they have black instruc-
tors but I don't think we can do that in Iowa City or even in the
state of Iowa. There are very few black instructors here. So the
possibility that you can do a lot for the child yourself before they
get to school is one out. You inevitably run into that authority
thing with white people but hopefully, by then, the child will have
some background about himself and about what to expect going to
school--things you couldn't warn 'em about when they go to daycare
at 2 or 3 years old. I guess the only relationship I can see with

white daycare centers dealing with third world children is that
it's likened to--and we can learn things from different systems--
dealing with black economic development where white people have all

the money and all black people have is human resources, you know,
and the ability, of course, to deal with each other that white
people don't have. White people can offer facilities and--when pos-
sible--financial arrangements. But most of the things they can of-
fer is usually never in the contact stage, where they come in dir-
ect contact with those people because that's just a hassle, you
know, white people haven't gotten to the point where they can deal
with black children or black people on a monetary basis without be-
coming very discriminating, and--especially monetarily--very rac-
ist. So the only thing that daycare centers that are white can
offer is space and offer some expertise--if there is any--how to
finance daycare centers, how to build them, how to apply for feder-
al funds. As far as populating the daycare center, in a position of
authority, I don't think that that should happen at all.

Q: Is there any black daycare at all in Iowa City?

A: No. They were talking about it. There is a group called

EBONY SISTERHOOD in Iowa City, of which I'm not a part 'cause
they're married. But they're talking about black daycare and
setting up something, perhaps. I'm not even sure how far they've
gone, even if they've left. Des Moines has a couple and they may
have gone down there to see how they run it (if they haven't they
should) but that's in the planning stage. Heretofore there haven't
been any black children at any age level enough to deal with it.
The transient population--here two to four years at the most--at
the time--there weren't more than 5 or 6 at any age. It's real
hard to set up a daycare center for two or three children. And the
other children who've been here forever have always participated in
staying home with their mother. (laughing) As far as black stud-
ents, other students with children, either the wife was at home or
they were both students and they would have to have a sitter be-
cause, you know, there was nothing they felt any confidence in.
With the black student population growing, I think the need for a
daycare center is becoming imminent. And they'll deal with it, but
before there hasn't been more than 10, I think, at one time, you
know, black children belonging to university students in any one
age group. So there've been very few babies around for people to
deal with. They were all either babies of a year or less or else
they were children in school.

Q: Do you have any feelings, being working class yourself, about
the supposed policies of Sparky to serve or give preference to
working class people? Sparky is not run by only middle class
people; there are a lot of working class people in it but I don't
know if you've ever heard anyone--like Sarah--talk about how she
was really offended when the idea came up of just serving working
class people. She thought that idea came just out of middle class
guilt and she thought that that was sort of messed up. Do you have
any feelings about that? Race may come into it so much that it may
make it an invalid question.

A: I guess to start off with I should make a statement about the
whole middle class guilt thing. It doesn't bother me so much that
middle class people feel guilty if that's not the level they stay
on. If we don’t get anything done because we think that it's
middle class guilt--that's where we get our money and that’s where
we get some ability to gather some knowledge so we can get rid of
'em. The thing is, if you're going to get as bogged down about
their guilt as they are, then, what the hell? They're bogged

down in being guilty and you don't want 'em to come over 'cause
they're guilty. You don't have no power! And that's one of the
major problems with working class and lower class people: they
don't have no power. And middle class people have some. They
don't have as much as the upper class people, but they have some
power, you know. If we could get all the power, that'd be great.
But I don't think that should stand in the way of working class
people being able to use middle class people to get the things
that they want. You don't have to stand around and hold their
hand because they're busy wanting to be flagellated because
they're guilty. The fact that they're usually very weak by the
time they get to that stage--you can channel their energies into
something useful. If they're going to stand around being guilty,
that takes up a lot of space. And the thing is, if they got
nothing better to do, then find something for them to do.

Q: So, like a daycare center would be finding something for

them to do...

A: The thing is that middle class people with little money can
volunteer their time. Working class people can't. They're gonna
starve if they don't work. So you can't say, "We don't want them
around 'cause they're guilty, we'll go off and start our own day-
care center." The problem is, without any money working class peo-
ple can't do that 'cause they can't spare the time to sit around all
day watching their kids. They might as well be home if they're
going to watch their kids. And they could do that at home and
watch T.V. The thing is: you've gotta be able to use the re-
sources that are available. And, if you have to--just speaking
on a total level of white people: upper, middle, and lower class,
not coming in with a racial thing but just as a class thing--the
only thing the lower class has that it can use is manipulation.
And they've got to be able to manipulate those other classes to
get power, to get money, so they can survive. It's not just getting
money so you can count on it, but getting money so you can eat;
getting your fair share of the pie and the Gross National Product
that everyone's so proud of and that lower class people are getting
none of and making all of for those big people. If I could get some
rich person's money I'd feel good; I wouldn't turn my back and walk
away 'cause he was rich. Being poor, no matter what anybody says, I
don't think is very much fun. I see nothing to smile about when
you're hungry. Lower class people with children don't like to see
their kids go hungry, don't like to see every Christmas go by with
their children having nothing, and their days in school start
with nothing. That may look like a lot of fun and virtuous to
people who are middle class and are poor because they feel like
being it for 4 years in school. Turning your back on people be-
cause they're middle class is a real luxury in itself. It says
something about where your head is and that's just not where most
working class people are that are really working class. Because,
if you can manipulate those people, by God, do it. I think that
starting daycare centers and getting money from middle class
people and being able to use them, and if you're going to use

them in your daycare center and you don't like their politics,
get rid of the ones that you can, but talk to those other ones.
You should be able to tell 'em exactly what you want 'em to do

and let 'em do it, because if you're really working class--that's
it, you're off working--you're not sitting at a daycare center.
By all means, don't just say, "because they're there I'll let 'em
run my kids crazy because they're middle class." Manipulate 'em,
talk to 'em; there's an education level. Tell 'em exactly what
you want 'em to do with the kids, what you don't want 'em to do
and then, if they don't like that, fine. I think you should have
something to say over how they deal with your kids. They should
not have anything to say over how the money's spent. Use their
expertise, if they know something you don't. Working class people
and lower class people don't have resources because it's been kept
away from them. To throw away a chance at a resource, I think is
pretty foolhardy.

“The Enormous Contradiction
We Have Sold Ourselves”

The murder and suicide of Pat Cone and her ex-husband, respec-
tively, in Lone Tree last week is too "close to home" both liter-
ally (because she worked and had friends here in Iowa City) and sym-
bolically (because every woman has seen and/or felt violence done
by a man or men to her or a woman close to her) for us to just let
it go by.

At the same time we saw the repeated fatal beatings, stranglings,
shootings of women by men close to them (we hear/see it on the
radio, TV, and newspapers every day) not as isolated incidents or
peculiar private crimes but as the product of the values our soc-
iety cherishes and promotes.

Males are socialized to see violence towards others, espec-
ially females, as a sign of affection. Females are socialized to
disarm their natural, self-protective instincts and to accept that
"VIOLENCE=LOVE" double-think as truth. For males in our culture,
violence serves two purposes: (1) as a defense and outlet for
hostility and (2) as a love message, a way of communicating af-
fection (or deep caring). "I can't live without you," so popular
in our songs and romantic myths translates easily into: "so I'll
die unless I can have you." Similarly, "I don't want you to live
without me" becomes "I'll kill you if you leave me."

In school and families around the time of puberty, girls are
taught to double-think when violence is done to them by boys, to not
react naturally and fight back, but rather to interpret a boy's
hitting them as "he loves me!" This brainwashing is an important
factor in preventing a woman from taking action to stop a man's
hurting her. Similarly, it works as an effective stop to anyone
else's interfering when a man is seen—say, on the street—hitting
a woman. Onlookers assume that because it is or may be a lover's
quarrel, it's "their business" only.

Even the laws enforce that kind of mentality. In most states
there has been legal support of men's violent crimes against wives

A Woman?

June

22, 1973

or female lovers. Men's crimes in these cases usually take a
lesser penalty—manslaughter, for example, in the event of the
woman's death; whereas women's slaying their husbands or male
lovers often is seen as murder in the first degree. In some states,
even with the same charge, a woman has gotten a stiffer sentence
for her "family crime."

The enormous contradiction we have sold ourselves—that some-
one is beating someone else because he loves her—puts women who
relate to violent male lovers (this is, sooner or later, most men
in our society) in the hideous double-bind of always hoping for
affection from the person who physically abuses her. How can she
prevent her own harm? He might be nice tonight when he comes
home, so, she reasons, she shouldn't leave or call on friends or
the police to deter him from hurting her. Anticipating his vio-
lence might bring it down on her, she fears. And, anyway, he
may beat me a little when he's upset but he's never seriously hurt
me.

Violence is violence. We should not see "slapping her around
a little” as different in kind (only in degree) from the violence
that ends in fatal beatings, stranglings, knifings, shootings.
Everything begins little. Extreme violence is not exceptional; it
is the natural escalation of small violent acts.

The number and frequency of beatings and other violent crimes
as a cause of women's deaths in this society are so common as to
be ignored as an unchangeable part of "the way things are."

But nothing is unchangeable. We need all women to get together
with other women you know to talk about male violence against
yourselves or women close to you.
Sharing that grief and anger will help us understand what we live/
have lived under, and will help us decide how to put an end to that
oppression.

The story of Goldflower is well-known in China. A woman badly
abused by her husband, Goldflower gained support in "speak bitter-
ness" meetings with other wives in her town. As a group, they
warned Goldflower's husband that violence has no place in his
treatment of his wife. Still, he beat her. Then the women of the
town went together to his house and beat him. Convinced, he changed
his behavior; so did other men in the town.

Violence is no kin to loving. We must not lie to ourselves
about that anymore. We must teach our children the truth, too.

We must enforce our demand that violence against women stop. To do
that we must begin where we are, now.

Castrating  
bitches  

Dedicated to Sarah Ottens  

Our goal is to regain control of our own bodies and lives.  
Yet, I am always amused and often greatly irritated to  
hear claims that the women's movement seeks to  
emasculate men. I should like to point out the irony of it.  
Women’s bodies have been subjected to men’s  
imaginations and manipulations for centuries.  

There were the pre-revolutionary Chinese who broke  
their women’s feet and socialized them into believing they  
were more beautiful that way when in reality they had  
fixed it so that their women could never run away from  
their slave positions.  

There were Moslem men who buried their women under  
veils and robes in the sweltering desert sun in order to  
inhibit their own sexual desires.  

There were the American bluecoats who sliced the  
genitals of Indian men and women, wearing the women's  
genitals on their hats for sport.  

There were the tortures of chastity belts, those iron girdles  
which not only prevented a woman's freedom of  
choice, but which were unbearable, cold contraptions  
which collected filth and disease. Women were left at home  
burning with disease while their Christian soldiers were  
raping Moslem women or lying dead on battlefields, the  
chastity belts’ keys gone forever.  

Freud managed to further louse things up for women by  
subjecting their psyches to his male interpretations of  
female sexuality. Post-Freudian doctors operated on  
women, removing their clitorises so they would experience  
the vaginal orgasms that Freud thought to be more mature  
than the “immature” clitoral orgasms.  

There were women who, because of church doctrine,  
were burned as witches, who died or suffered from forced  
motherhood or in the hands of illegal abortionists because  
the patriarchal church banned birth control and abortion.  
All these, not to mention countless women past and present  
in all societies who have been subjected by men to  
beatings, rape, murder and prostitution.  

Certainly when I think of all these inhuman,  
premeditated cruelties that women's bodies have endured  
due to whims of their menfolk, I must laugh in rage against  
some man's fear of being emasculated. When I dream of  
the inner rage of women collectively coming together for a  
purpose, and think: **Castration?’’...It would be too kind.  

The demystified Fortress  

Then,  

If I stole your armor,  
Your tron suit, lance,  
Face guards, epaulets,  
And put them in the Museum  
Under the Tower  
Where I secretly practiced  
Wearing them.  

I even perfected  
Your signature  

On my death warrant,  
Daddy,  
ALL of you aromatre,  
Robins-egg blue.  

Then I sat in the glass Tower  
Wondering if you could see me  
without my tron vest  

Or red wig; like Queen Bess  
Imagined letting your severed head  
Bleed over my velvet robe.  

--Barbara Unger
