Ten out of thirteen pregnancies

caught my mother's womb

at 18 tender years,

And gave her no rest until they took it away
at 39 tired ones, so she could keep working.
I lost,

Nine lives that she survives

in debt, deeper every year,

and in poor health—

make no mistake about that POOR health.

She gave up what could have been an easier life,
the single life,

for a place in Heaven, and one fucker.

That lost single-ness

and the color of her skin

could have cushioned her after a hard childhood.
But she gave up the first,

in fact, saw no choice... She says:
And in her world the second was the Rule, "And Grandpa is old before his time.
she could eat, marry, and live in her town, He's sixty-two and it's like he's eighty. 
and be oblivious to the oppression of others. They won't let him work outside anymore.

She's never realized a lot of her own. He's at a desk....shuffling papers,

and he's miserable, he feels useless.
And he's sick—

He can't even have a beer these days."
What can I say to that painful news?

And she prayed. Grandpa's plight catches my throat,

not out of fear for myself, but him
AND SHE'S STILL PRAYING— and my mother, who's headed that way.

to earn salvation and mercy for her kids and husband, I only mouth a defense of our class,
whom she's condemned countless times. and she doesn't give a shit what I say.
Her older daughters don't believe, really— I realize that she'll defend her life,
and her young children could defect anytime. and fight to change mine.
I keep hoping, and God knows, I'VE TRIED. And she stubbornly plugs on:
"Get a job where you go to work from 9 to 5,
I was her first,
pay your debts, and get some security for the future
and so I'm told, the most trouble. don't kid yourself, things are getting rougher.
He always told me I was the worst, Like be a clerk in a store,
and I hate him, for check-out girls at Eagle's make $3.00 an hour."
So I tell her that carpenter's apprentices start higher,
and that men have all the job security,
even though all men don't.
My bones and bruises are healed. And I live in another town, besides.
I also won the last fight I had with him.
My mother wants me to make it,

But my sister, fourth in line, is catching the shit, now. and still keep the ethics.
And I can't really ease her pain, but I will stay working-class,
just warn her and hope she fights back sometimes, and I won't have to try.

to ward off hope:
Listen to me, mom.
I love you,
but I love myself and our people, too—
and I don't mean the Mother Church,
or racist, sexist, club-wielding men.
You like music, dancing, and slapstick comics,
I do, too.
You want your kids to eat well,
wear adequate clothing

and be clean.

I never understood class by any name,

But I can see where my consciousness came from.
I resisted staying in the Working Class

until they ripped off my last buck,

and now I'm in debt, too,

without even a year's credit,

and certainly without grace.

My sisters haven't been led on,

and will not make my mistake.

So do I.
I am a feminist and a lesbian,
so my mother and I talk about class now. When I was younger
I thought she'd die if she ever found out about
my life and my politics.
and she sometimes makes bitter comments. Well, she's found out enough to tumble the cathedral,
those goddam prayers.
If I had a nickel for every rosary...
She often berates me because she thinks I pay my debts,
with no respect for anything or anybody.
Once I wanted to change my last name
to her first name.
It only embarrassed her. She says my brains
She didn't understand, and I can't explain.
Maybe I just wanted to get back at the old man. It's hard to get things going,

like the revolution.
It's hard enough to survive
without going crazy for good.
It beats me how women without friends make it.
I tell her I want to be a carpenter, in this world.

She matters to me and my name hasn't changed.

or a printer or a mechanic— beats me where the money comes from

and all she can say is: unless it's from the top.
"You're not built for that kind of work. 
You think you're a real athlete? 
You just want a man's job, that's sick.
When you've got some talent and creativity 
you've got no business digging ditches." 
And when I say: 
"That's bullshit, and Grandpa works at Goodyear. If he can, so can I."
I want to.

The following is an “Ain't I A Woman?” Message:

Lots of new plans and positions on where-it's-at, where-it-was, what-to-do, how-to-do-it, etc... are coming up in what some may call the women's movement. What we're all hearing is dialogue and arguments between women in our community and in other cities based on the subject matter of books and long essays. Basically, these are *Lesbian Nation* by lesbian Vi e Voice columnist and feminist Jill Johnston; *The First Sex* by Elizabeth Gould Davis and *Mother Right: A New Feminist Theory* by Jane Alpert, a former Weather affiliate and political fugitive feminist. We have been trying to get information and other women's opinions about the issues created by these books, and mostly have been pretty confused and not often satisfied. Only recently it began to dawn that all these new issues are part of an academic haze parading as the going politics and correct direction for lesbians, feminists, and separatists. We have all been arguing and searching for arguments about lesbian nation, mother right, gynarchy, and matriarchy in the name of an idea, and are failing to examine the source and its cover.

*Ain't I A Woman?* has been concerned about finding out about all these new issues so that we could sort out what should be criticized and what should be pursued. We haven't been objectively interested, either; lots of things put us off. Talk and plans of lesbian farms, goddesses, breeding out men, emphasizing culture and art, glorifying motherhood, and other such things all leave some women out in the cold, with their needs consistently ignored. Most of these women are the same women that get fucked over by the racist, male class system, consistently. We are some of those women, and that's where we're at.

We hear about lesbians being pitted against each other over the presence of a male transsexual at their conference (or somebody's conference), and for sure some women are getting fucked over there, and incorrect lines plus repressive tactics mean getting fucked over as much as a male presence does. Women called the Los Angeles conference a lot of things, including the birth of the lesbian nation, which seems presumptuous. What do conscious women expect, anyway, in the middle of a big university campus, under the close, opportunistic eye of the press and with Ronald Reagan's permission? Subversion, division, and exploitation are never accidents, and the state of California is never going to allow the birth of a revolution (which is what we need), let alone finance it and house it. Neither is Random House, Doubleday, Simon and Schuster, CBS, PBS, the Washington Post, or *Ms.* magazine.

We hear about lesbians who have enough money, property, and credit starting to buy land for rural communes and calling themselves "nations," as if the fight has already been won and there is all this "free land" for "free people." How the fuck do women who are, for the most part, naive city-dwellers, dependent on urban services and the labor of other human beings, expect to handle droughts, insects, flooded fields, and all the other trials and labors of a farmer? With hired hands? Servants? How do these women, even if they learn modern methods and get all that expensive machinery, survive in the face of agribusiness and Nixon's economy? Farmers who are not big-money guys get their crops in and their animals to market with the help of other farmers and sharing equipment. And they suffer harder losses every year until they sell, against their will. There aren't going to be any bunches of lesbians next door, and primitive agriculture will not suffice. Not since the Industrial Revolution has this been possible, and not without the deaths of six billion human beings could it ever be done again, especially considering all the healing this planet needs. Short-sighted separatists determined not to relate to men would die quickly (unless supported by those of us "sell-outs" who have to work for a living), though true to their principles, in rural America. The grain elevators, railroads, stockyards, service co-ops, and markets are all owned and controlled by pig, capitalist men. And certainly, these women would be forced to defend "their" land and lifestyles against the rural people (who become the police when they are threatened) because isolating oneself totally from oppression can only be achieved by suicide.

Dear women and sisters, I never admitted how much hatred there was there (at school), never admitted my struggle as beginning class. I saw how the college perpetuated in me class values which didn't belong to me. I just wanted to write you to tell you how important *Ain't I A Woman* has been to me. When I first started subscribing, I was in a small women's college in rural New York, had never met or read a lesbian woman, and was having an incredibly difficult time accepting my own gayness though I'd been gay my whole life. Not only did *Ain't I A Woman* put me in touch with anger and sense of oppression, but more than anything else I read clear-headedness, working things out, a sense of commitment, community, joy, even love. That was important, for besides finally admitting and getting in touch with pain and anger, it gave me something to move towards - yes, some lesbians are really, really getting it together - and that gave me courage. I was so, so afraid of moving, but I began to dream of moving out and helping you write the paper, and in the meantime, I came out as the only open lesbian on campus. I faced great hostility, rejection, denial, sex objectification, and built some tenuous, mistrustful relationships with some closeted women who came to me.

I lay awake nights, amazed by what you said, scared I could never be the kind of revolutionary I knew I had to be. You gave me a handle on the revolution, a way I could grab it, grapple with it, use it. I'm in an eastern city now. It's so much nicer being with gay women that the worst struggle seems past, even though the stakes are higher. There are so many gay women here, and such security, and I hadn't realized that the reason I was more restless was that they'd already been through solidarity, that the reason I felt the gay community was because I wasn't a part of it. That's partly true; there still is a need for the solidarity, real communication, and clarity of vision I see in your paper. I'm beginning to talk to women about that, to have the courage and initiative to gather a collective to go deeper than the comfortable place we've been.

I don't mean to idealize you, but I do have profound respect for you. We hear about *The First Sex* and Jane Alpert's new theory and how women are into a return of Matriarchal Rule, goddess worship, honoring motherhood, etc. Many of us cannot relate to ancient history in very many concrete ways, maybe because it's so academic and irrelevant to our lives in the here and now. Motherhood is a frightening and complex thing to glorify. To many women, motherhood only means pain and hardship, and is something to escape, destroy, or at least de-emphasize. Motherhood as a woman's basic identification and role-to-be-respected is part of the heterosexual sexist rap we want to beat. Childcare is an issue for women, and we want to relate to it and deal with it because it is a need of women. However, in lots of cases, being allowed to do childcare, as lesbians, is another trip. Restrictions, rip-offs, and repression are being laid on us by the people who want to glorify mothers and motherhood, be they feminist or lesbian mothers, or state investigators, acting as agents of those who prefer heterosexuality, sexism, and the nuclear family.

We hear about cloning and XY chromosomes and how if women stopped having male children that men would die out in 68 years. It's been said that women have poured energy into our history and our future, but that no one is dealing with the present and the war we need to change things. It would take much longer than 68 years to get women to stop producing male children, unless dykes are talking about taking control of people's lives to institute such a fucked-up priority dream. No men suits us fine, but for a white, middle-class-dominated movement to talk so glibly about exterminating all men is genocidal, because most men and most women are not white and are disenfranchised and oppressed by the ruling classes and governments that were the first to think of killing off undesirables, anyway, including lesbians. We know that women of color who are feminists, lesbians, and separatists are man-haters. We know that poor and working-class white feminists, lesbians, and separatists are man-haters, because we are some of those women. It is not outrageous to hear Third World women condemn the power and pigshit of men of their races. Those women are under those men in this society; white middle-class women are not. The rage of those of us who are working-class against men is real; it is our right. It's painful and infuriating to think of those well-fed women taking pride in beating or murdering, at random, men whose bodies are possibly sick, tired, and weak from being overworked and undernourished. This is not to say that women should not begin making immediate, violent retaliations against male institutions and male attackers, in whatever way we see fit. And it is not to say that we should not kill men if that is what it takes to blast away this shit pile once and for all.

I'm thinking that many women are going to attack or dismiss what is said here as male left ad nauseum, etc., that being such an effective threat against feminists; but I'll wager that most women with their shit together, especially about class or race, will understand exactly what is being talked about. If all this pre-revolutionary energy for genocide were refocused on trying to start the fights that will lead to being able to eat, live, and have the right of self-determination (important idea, there), life'd be bearable. But maybe this energy isn't really energy, but more haze and distraction. It's increasingly obvious that even in the women's movement, even in radical lesbian groups, that poor and Third World women are invisible; we do not exist to the Amazons, artists, Matriarchists, and media-pushers. Women do not have to read *Lesbian Nation* or *The First Sex* to "know where it's at in the women's movement," and should not have to hear any woman tell us we do. Academic and literary world women should not push culture, art, and their intelligentsia standards down our throats. These things are not a part of most women's lives and struggles. Lesbians should not palm off the heterosexual "mother right" on other lesbians, mothers, and non-mothers alike.

Coming up with a realistic analysis of things starts with recognizing who we are and what our needs are. All of us, and all of our real needs. Being "uncultured," "uneducated," and isolated from hip trips is not the pitiful life. Being hungry and dependent and sick in our bodies from being denied even minimal unoppressive medical care is the lot of most women and most lesbians and most female children, and these needs should be paramount to revolution-minded dykes. Let's stop eating up media traps and tempting professional interests. Let's find real meat to sink our teeth into, literally.

I respect that you write about your community of women and yourselves, and detail that struggle, because I believe that is the level where politics, action, and revolution are made. I respect you for putting revolution in such a concrete form that I can really grapple with it. I respect you for not compromising what you say. I disagree with people who don't think your paper speaks to those new to feminism. I came to your paper as politically naive as any, and as scared, confused, and self-hating as any, and I saw the clarity of it, and it may have kept me awake nights, but thank god for that. With me at least your paper succeeds in that it helps me clarify directions and goals and stirs me to action. It shakes me up.

I've wanted to write to you a long time, but felt inadequate, inarticulate. Doing tae kwon do has helped me put my anger into good solid fighting and somehow that has helped the words flow. I think I would like to have a relationship with you, writing to and for you as my writing gets better if you want. You can do with this letter what's useful to you, publish it if you want.

I'd like your complete volumes #1 & 2. I've had some of those copies I think, but I keep giving them away to women sitting next to me on buses and so on...

Best of my hopes for you. With deep felt thanks and love,

Kathy

TERMS BEING WHAT THEY ARE, IT WOULD SEEM MORE

HERSELF!

WRITE WOMEN BACK

INTO HISTORY

we DO have a history!

If the silence of the
historians is taken
to mean anything,

it would appear that
one-half of our po-
pulation have been
negligible factors

in our country's his-
tory. (Arthur M.
Schlesinger, Sr. New
Viewpoints in Ameri-
can History, 1922)

Fifty years ago an eminent
male historian called at-
tention to the gross neglect
of women in the standard
interpretations of American
history. It didn't do much
good, did it? How many of us
in the countless history
courses that we were fed in
public school or even college,
ever encountered a woman who
was important? If the authors
of textbooks felt compelled
to mention women, they
brought in two or three appa-
rent oddballs--Carrie Nation,
the temperance worker who
chopped down bars was a favo-
rite--leaving us with the
impression that real, normal
women have never been an in-
tegral part of American history.
This will be a regular
column that will discuss the
history of women in America,
as one way to begin to under-
mine the myth that only men
have had a history. The co-
lumn will take a variety of

forms--short biographies of
interesting women, book re-
views and discussions of the
conditions of women in the
past. Out of this we can
begin to know a little more
about our history.

The column might also
lead us to other questions.
Just what does the history
of women in America involve?
Does it mean rewriting male
WASP history to include

female superstars?

Or perhaps female history
should begin at the opposite
end with an examination of the
history of the family, that
intimate institution in which
most ordinary women have lived
out their lives. But who
was the “ordinary woman"? Was
there ever such a person? Was
she the middle-class leisured
lady or the farm girl hired
to work in the textile mill?
Was she the Southern planta-
tion wife or her house slave?
What were the differences
among American women that
created the variations in the
experience of growing up female
in America? And beyond these
differences, was there a common
experience out of which a
feminist consciousness could
have developed? Did we develop
a female culture alongside
the dominant male culture?
Despite the neglect of wo-
men in the history texts,

there are many isolated books
with which we can begin the
task of putting ourselves back
into history. I will mention
a couple of these each issue.
To begin with, if you want to
get a general, overall picture
of the history of American
women, there are a couple of
good paperbacks out that
should be available at either
Together Books or RIP Bookstore.
Andrew Sinclair's The Emancipa-
tion of the American Woman

(also available in hardback at the
library under the title The
Better Half) is a very readable
history that does a fair job
of dealing with more than just
superwomen and the women's
movement. The Woman in American
History (190 pp.) by Gerda
Lerner is shorter and was writ-
ten as a high school text.
However, it probably gives the
best short, overall picture
presently available.

I hope that this column will
reflect your interests as well
as mine. Please write and let
me know what you would like
me to write about as well as
your reactions to what I've
written. Susan Spragg Jones,
1653 Jackson Street, Denver,
80206.

MOVIE REVIEW

Stand Up & Be Counted

The story line is stereo-
typically simple. Three main
characters--one a super-career
woman, one a hassled housewife,
and one a sex symbol married to
a business tycoon make up the
characters. Each, in her own
way, works out her personhood.

I won't dull the movie for you
by going into detail.

I do have strong positive and
negative feelings. One good
thing is that it is clearly
stated that there is no individ-
ual liberation. All women are
in the struggle together. The
movie showed women as strong,
sensitive people, capable of
changing their lives.

The "bad" are along the lines
of political criticism. The movie
didn't deal at all with the problems
of consumer capitalism. The women
in the movie are dressed like fa-
shion models, with full make-up and,
one assumes, vaginal deodorant.

The movie implies that, if a woman
wants to be liberated, she can go
out and get a tremendously satis-
fying job making tons of money. (Fat
chance) One of the sub-plots ques-
tions the right of a factory owner
to pay women less than men; it
never questions his right to own

the factory. Etc., etc., etc.

There are moments in the movie
that really embarrassed me with its
clumsiness. The "consciousness-
raising group scene" was clearly
made by someone never remotely con-

nected with consciousness-raising.

The movie briefly mentions les-
bians, poor women, older women, etc.,
but one shot on each subject is
hardly “in depth."

The way Senior Women's Liberation
was handled was degrading. It was
pretty clearly a man's view of older
women.

I think this review is a lot
more negative than is necessary.

For all its faults, I think you
will leave feeling excited and happy.

Even knowing that I was being
co-opted, I loved seeing women be-
ing "together."

Anne Bennett

The thing that makes a physi-
cian a very special person is his
decision to dedicate himself to
the practice of medicine. Except
for this universal dedication
every doctor is different, just
as every man is different. It is
your adjustment to the individual
doctor who is your husband and
the life you must lead because of
his dedication that will determine
what kind of a doctor's wife you
will be.

A former president of the AMA
has said: "Nothing is as impor-
tant in shaping a doctor's career
as is his wife and home. The doc-
tor's wife must share his ideal-
ism, appreciate a standard of
values held by no other group and
give him an understanding re-
quired by few. Being a doctor's
wife is both a career and an art."

In any career or art there are
techniques to be mastered. So it
is with the career of being a doc-
tor's wife. Of the necessary
techniques or qualities, I would
first list unselfishness. You
must learn to be unselfish with

“What is a Doctor? —

(What is a Doctor’s Wife?)

your husband because whether you
like it or not, he belongs first
to his profession. In your in-
nocence when you married him you
probably thought the phrase in
the ceremony "In sickness and in
health" meant just you two. You
were wrong for with a physician
it really means the sickness and
health of the whole community.
You must unselfishly share him
with his patients, with medical
meetings and all the other things
that are required of him if he is
to be a good doctor. The very
nature of his profession makes him
public property.

You will understand the need
for patience with your children.
They will not have the insight a-
bout their Dad's preoccupation
with his profession. Your atti-
tude can be most important in
teaching your children to respect
their father's dedication. Your
teaching can make your children
know that their dad does "good"
for others and because of this he
cannot always be there when his
children want him.

A third quality is self-reli-
ance. You must learn to make de-
cisions yourself--decisions that
other women call upon their hus-
bands to make. You will have to
make decisions about your home,
your children, your attitude to-
ward life; you must lead the home-
front.

These then are some of the
qualifications of a good doctor's
wife--she is unselfish, patient,
self-reliant. A good marriage to
a doctor is partnership. It is
something that both of you will
slave to work at to attain. It
doesn't just happen. The wife
has more than an equal share of
the responsibility to see that
the partnership is a good one. I
am reminded of a passage from
Kahlil Gibran's book, "The
Prophet" from the part in which
he speaks of marriage. He says:

You shall be together, But

let there be spaces in

your togetherness

Love one another, but make

not a bond of love;

Fill each other's cup, but

drink not from one cup

Give one another of your

bread, but eat not from

the same loaf;

Sing and dance together

and be joyous, but let

each of you be alone

Though they quiver with
the same music, the
strings of the lute are
alone.

And stand together yet not
too near, For the pillars
of the temple stand apart

And the oak and the cy-
press grow not in each
other's shadow. . ."

Mrs. B.L. Robertson

He might have had the doctor
and his wife in mind when he wrote
those beautiful lines. As a
doctor's wife your first responsi-
bility is to your husband, your

family, your home. You may some-
times rebel against making so
many decisions on your own, a-
gainst so much disciplining of
your emotions but the reward will
be great. What more could you
ask than a contented husband and
happy children?

Fee

. . . AND HERE’S TO YOU, MRS. ROBERTSON

:

My first response to Mrs.  
Robertson's article is anger  
mixed with a little sadness, too,  
that another woman would write  
such a sugar-coated, dogmatic,  
sentimentalized, and destructive  
guide to how other women should  
define their existence.

I am a doctor's wife. I do not  
consider it a "career" to be  
one. It is a relationship that  
I have with another person who  
happens to be a doctor. As a  
separate individual with my own  
needs, (to grow, to be dedicated,  
to contribute to the community),  
I resent anyone telling me to de-  
fine myself in terms of another  
person and his needs. Mrs.  
Robertson says that I must "make  
an adjustment" to my husband and  
the life he has chosen, and that  
that "adjustment" will determine  
the kind of life I will lead.

No, thank you, Mrs. Robertson.  
I have my own needs, my own life  
to choose and to create; my life  

is not a series of adjustments in  
my husband's direction. Rather I  
see our life, ideally, as an e-  
qual experience of sharing—of  
giving and taking, and part of  
that sharing is the protesting to-  
gether the medical system that  
denies my being a person in my  
own right and denies my husband  
the same thing.

The medical power structure  
has set it up so that a doctor is  
considered “public property.”

The conflict that the individual  
doctor feels between his public  
life and his private needs stems  
from the irresponsible attitude  
of the medical profession which  
maintains a shortage of doctors  
and a hierarchical structure of  
roles within the medical system  
in its own interest. By mini-  
mizing its responsibility to the  
community, the medical profes-  
sion puts the responsibility on  
the individual doctor who feels  
isolated in this conflict and  
powerless to resolve it. This  
idea that a doctor is public prop-  
erty is part of the mystification  
of what a doctor is—that doesn't  
allow him feelings in dealing  
with his profession, or the choice  
of making his private life as im-  
portant to him as his public life,  
or allow him to make a mistake,  

to admit uncertainty, to deal in  
a human way with the human beings  
he is serving.

Mrs. Robertson, you give me  
three "qualifications for being  
a good doctor's wife." Unself-  
ishness is the first one. Like  
most women, I have been raised  
to be unselfish—to put others'  
needs before my own. I have  
found that it is not a virtue to  
be unselfish at all times, es-  
pecially around this issue of  
being a doctor's wife. It is this  
"unselfishness" that separates  
women who are doctor's wives and  

keeps them from openly sharing  
the pain they experience because  
they and their husbands have been  
indoctrinated into thinking, as  
you say, that “whether you like  
it or not, he belongs first to  
his profession." No. He belongs  
first to himself and he can de-  
termine the priorities in his own  
life. By accepting this defini-  

tion of medicine being a doctor's  
entire life, we cannot trust our  
own feelings and protest when our  
husbands, as interns and resi-  
dents, are forced to work 100 out  
of 168 hours in a week—when we  
see them exhausted physically and  
emotionally by the pressures of  
work—or when they have invested  
so much time and energy into their  
work that they lose interest in  
other people or even in question-  
ing the very system which is de-  
humanizing them. Perhaps this is  
why so many doctors are seen as  
cold, uncaring, unable to deal  
with their own faults and feel-  
ings. It must be hell to be ex-  
pected to be perfect, dedicated,  
to play God, when you know in-  
side that you are only a human  
being like everyone else.

I want to join with other  
people (doctor's wives, doctors,  
students, other health profession-  
als, etc.) in demanding that a  
doctor's training be a human ex-  
perience—that he and I be given  
time and space to grow in the  
directions we choose for our-  
selves, and have the right to de-  
fine for ourselves what is im-  
portant in our lives at any given  
time. 

Mrs. Robertson, you say I must  
also be "patient" to qualify as  
a "good" doctor's wife. I am  
patient with my children; I am  
also aware of my impatience with  
them, an impatience which stems  
from knowing that I carry most of  
the responsibility for raising  
them. But I will not lie to them.  
I will not tell them that it is  
my husband's "dedication to do  
good" for others which keeps him  
away from them, when I know he  
would rather be sharing his life  
more fully with them—knowing  
them as I know them. I will  
teach them to be impatient with  
the system that makes too many  
demands on their father's time  
and energy. That denies him his  
own needs as a human being. The  
justification for overworking  
doctors is that there is a short-  
age of doctors. True, there is  

a shortage of doctors, but it is  
the medical power hierarchy which  
maintains and encourages that  
shortage in its own interests.

I will also teach my children  
that.

Third, Mrs. Robertson, you say  
that I must be self-reliant.

Part of the strength of being  
self-reliant is knowing what your  
limits are, where your resent-  
ments begin, and what you need as  
a person. I will not "discipline  
my emotions" as you suggest, ac-  
cepting without question the role  
of a doctor's wife. I will trust  
my emotions as good indicators of  
what is wrong with the expecta-  
tions that are being made of me.  
Any rebelling against these ex-  
pectations and the system that  
created them, I consider a sign  
of mental health.

I would like to rewrite your  
last paragraph: As a person in  
my own right, my first responsi-  
bility is to myself—to under-  
standing and dealing with my own  
needs and feelings. Only after  
that can I deal honestly with  

anyone else. I will rebel a-  
gainst the structure of the medi-  
cal profession which denies both  
my husband and myself the possi-  
bility of defining ourselves and  
creating our own lives. I see  
my role as a doctor's wife in  
supporting and getting support  
from my husband against that sys-  
tem. What more could I ask than  
to be my own person first, and to  
share that with the people  
closest to me?

Mona—what would she say if they let her speak

that speechless media quieted by a man's brush
her hands tied

The mammoths are exterminated.

TO MAN

The sabre-toothed tigers are dead.
The buffaloes are gone.

There is no large, dangerous animal left
for you to attack.

The fierceness that you show to me
and every living thing is misplaced.
You are ridiculous.

Will you not see

that I am your counterpart?

If you will not learn gentleness,

if you will not be kind,

I cannot love you.

I will shun your touch.

You may control me through fear

for a time.

But secretly

I will wish for you to die.

WOMEN in transition

I had a dream last month  
that I'd like to share with you.  
I dreamed I had finally left  
my husband; I passed through  
the door of his house and stood  
outside, where the sun shone on  
the green hills and valleys  
of the world. As I was looking  
around, wondering which house  
I would live in next, I slowly  
formed a question that had  
never been asked before.

"Why do I always have to live  
in some man's house?" Be-  
cause it suddenly occurred to  
me that women, too, could  
build houses: all they had to  
do was to realize that they  
could.

It wasn't too many years  
ago that women had to depend  
on men for all the necessi-  
ties of life. A woman, single  
or married, generally lived  
with her father, husband, son  
or some other male relative  
or employer. This isn't  
true anymore, of course, women  
can earn their own bread and  
live alone if they please,  
although we are slow to realize  
that this can be a serious  
lifetime choice.

But few people want to live  
alone, and here's where we are  
almost as dependent as ever.  
Women are still forced into the  
feminine role, not by number  
but by loneliness. For the  
one officially sanctioned source  
of closeness for women is  
marriage. Yet marriage (and  
most other couple relation-  
ships) separate us. In exchange  
for intimacy with one man, we  
separate ourselves from every  
one else--by centering our  
lives within single-family  
houses, by taking sole respon-  
sibility for our children,  
by treating other women as  
threats to this one intimacy.  
Men join force with each  
other every day, but for women  
--well, "divide and conquer"  
really works.

My dream was firmly  
rooted in my waking life,  
because I did leave my  
husband last fall, and I have  
indeed been trying to move  
out of my man-centered  
thinking and find my  
own way of living in the  
world. I've been in a  
good place for changing and  
growing, because I've been  
living in a community (Insti-  
tute Mountain West) which  
is not male dominated, and  
which provides much of the  
closeness I need without  
requiring the emotional  
tradeoffs that usually ac-  
company couple relationships.  
As a result, I now take  
communal living very seriously  
as a base for people learning  
to exercise their own  
strength. And particularly  
for women, who have been  
separated for so long and  
are now finding their  
strength through solidarity  
with each other.

For me, the difficulties  
in building a house for my-  
self have been psychic; fears  
(would our families and  
friends reject me?), uncer-  
tainties (could I really  
take care of myself?), guilt  
trips (what would this do  
to the children?). For many  
women, there are also practi-  
cal difficulties--full-time  
child care, no place to live,  
no money, no job skills.  
These problems can be para-  
lyzing for a woman alone.  
They can be overcome by women  
together.

So: a proposal. I would  
like to see a communal house  
in Denver for women only, a  
house whose main purpose is  
giving support to women who  
are trying to restructure their  
lives. Practical support;  

a place to live cheaply by  
sharing space and possessions,  
maybe temporarily free by  
sharing income. The opportu-  
nity to cooperate with sisters  
in child care. Maybe job  
sharing, or a job coop for  
part-time work. And psychic  
support; living with sisters in  
a community that encourages  
openness. Sharing our strug-  
gles, one to one or in groups,  
with other people who know  
what we're talking about.

Knowing that we aren't alone.

I see this house as a base from  
which women would have the  
chance to explore new living  
possibilities, and to feel their  
strength as women and  
with women. It would seem  
natural for this house to have  
shared child care for the resi-  
dents; it might also serve as  

a permanent home for a coop  
nursery school. Perhaps  

space for a women's center, a  
library or clinic?

There is some money avai-  
lable for this project; it  
should be possible to make a  
down payment on a building  
and, instead of pouring rent  
into a capitalistic landlord's  
pocket; liberate it in the form  
of a land trust permanently  
owned by the women who occupy  
it.

A lot of people have ex-  
pressed interest and support  
for this idea. What is needed  
right now is a few women who  
share my commitment to com-  
munal living, who would con-  
sider actually living in the  
house for several months and  
putting at least part-time  
time and energy into it. If  
that sounds like you, I'd like  
to hear from you. I can be  
reached at the Institute, 2096  
Emerson Street, or phone  
573-6394.

I see the article in Women,  
Vol. 2, No. 4, on the Philadel-  
phia Women's Transition House  
for a more detailed discussion  
of this idea.  
Iris Greene

motherhood. ..

I want to write a journal about  
myself as a woman and as a mother,  
to explore my thoughts in a deeper  
and more coherent way. I also want  
to share my own struggle because if  
I had been able to read something  
like this, I would never have felt  
so isolated and full of self-hate  
and doubts.

I think being pregnant and giving  
birth and then motherhood are  
very different experiences. For  
example, before finding out I was  
pregnant, I fantasized about being  
pregnant and giving birth and nursing.  
I didn't think about what it would  
mean on a day-to-day basis. Mo-  
therhood was so undifferentiated  

and idealized as a glorified state  
of being, as something I magically  
became; it got very confusing as I  
struggled to define how the ideal  
fit into my daily experiences.

After my second wedding anni-  
versary, I found out I was preg-  
nant. A diaphragm baby—a dia-  
phragm used carelessly because,  
well, I believe I wanted to have a  
baby. We more or less planned to  
get pregnant in a year or two's  
time.

As soon as I left the clinic,  

waiting for David to pick me up and—  

to tell him, I cried. I felt  
cheated because I had always looked  
forward to deciding consciously to  
get pregnant. I felt like a fail-  
ure because I saw myself as some-  
one who had control over such mat-  
ter-of-fact processes as birth con-  
trol. I also realized that David  
and I would no longer be totally in-  
dependent and without responsibili-  
ties. One reason for putting off  
getting pregnant was that I wanted  
more time alone with David.

It was really a matter of timing.  
On one hand, David and I figured  
there was never a perfect time.  
There was always something else to  
do—travel, education, work. On the  
other hand, "if not now, when?"

I always thought I would get  
pregnant after I got my career to-  
gether. We had fantasies of each  
of us getting half-time jobs while  
we had babies so we could share in  
their care, and taking turns working  
once the children (notice the plu-  
ral form) were older. Well, there  
I was, a first-year graduate student  
in Sociology at Berkeley, and I knew  
that I was not going to be a profes-  
sor one day. I was not going to

encompass the kind of soul-searching—and-sharing that breeds real sisterhood. Because

While in Berkeley, California, one of the women working on BIG MAMA met the woman  
who wrote the following journal, and brought it back to Denver for other women to  

It is a very long, thoughtful journal relating the concrete experiences of  

have one of those careers or be a  
traditional academic woman. Yet no  
alternate lifestyles appealed to  
me—regular movement politics or  
hippy hang loose. I wanted to do  
some meaningful work, but was con-  
fused about what kind of work to  
get into.

So there I was, dissatisfied with  
my work and vaguely figuring I  
could get some kind of fulfillment  
out of parenthood.

Now, two years later, obviously  
due a large part to being a mother  
of a 17-month-old girl, I see a  
career, travel, and education dif-  
ferently. My career will be inti-  
mately involved with the women's  
movement; I am more into internal  
journeys than travel to other lands,  
and I see my formal education in a  
much more utilitarian fashion—I  
use it to get a job (I am a teach-  
ing assistant), and will use a pro-  
gram to be trained in a skill if  
it is expedient.

But I am getting ahead of myself.  
I hadn't considered much about ac-  
tual motherhood—the caretaking and  
responsibility for a child or in-  
fant. Pregnancy and birth were the  
center of my fantasies as I thought  
about and decided to remain preg-  
nant.

I think at this point more de-  
tails of my personal biography are  
relevant. This was February 1969.

I had heard about women's libera-  
tion and welcomed it wholeheartedly  
as very relevant to my life. When  
I married, I thought I legally had to  
change my name. I did, and hated  
being Mrs. Him. When I arrived in  
Berkeley, I changed back to my mai-  
den name. I realize it is my fa-  
ther's name, but it was me for 22  
years and I never felt like I was  
Mrs. David Him.

I went through bureaucratic and  
emotional hassles doing that change.  
I felt like a lonely fanatic.  
"What's in a name?" is the message  
I got from my circle of leftish  
male graduate students. From David  
I got passive support. From the  
straight world at the University I  
got expressions of unbelief and  
hostility. From women friends I got  
tacit support, but many wondered if  
it was worth the hassle. But I had  
to do it for my state of mind. I  
did it in some slightly devious ways  
because I didn't have the energy or  
support for honest confrontations.

That Fall, I sought out a women's  
liberation small group. I went to  
two different ones. One had been  
going on and I felt I needed to be  
in one from the beginning. The next  
was composed of women connected to  
Berkeley male political heavies. It  
was very in-groupy and I felt left  
out. So I didn't go back. But I  
read available literature and saw  
my marriage as being liberated. I  
saw it like that for a couple of  
reasons. I no longer was Mrs. Him,  
and I shared the household tasks  
with my husband. I was unaware  
that I still felt and acted on the  
total responsibility for that work.  
In the Fall of 1968, I believed I  
had an equalitarian marriage, that  
when we had a child we would con-  
tinue being equal in child care.

So when I found out I was preg-  
nant, I used to say "we" are preg-  
nant. We planned to share the ex-  
perience in as total a way as we  
knew how.

I got into being pregnant. I  
had always looked forward to that  
time as one of joy and beauty. I  
didn't feel I was creating a being  
really. I used to tell people, "It  
is creating itself." I dug the  
changes in my body; it was a groovy  
physical experience. I read books  
about the natural process of preg-  
nancy. I found another woman who  
was pregnant and we shared experi-  
ences, pains and aches, doctor stor-  
ies and information on natural

childbirth. I loved to watch the  
changes in my body and to fantasize  
about the growth of a human being  
going on right inside me. I felt  
for the first time in years that my  
body really looked beautiful, and I  
got positive feedback about that  
from friends. It was a happy and  
exciting time for David and me.  
When I look back I can see some  
things I was blind to. What I  
thought was sharing being pregnant  
wasn't really sharing at all.  
While the baby was going to be ours  
in a real way, I was the one who  
desperately needed another woman to  
talk to. I was the one avidly read-  
ing pregnancy books. David read  
sections I suggested in various  
books, but he didn't feel the ab-  
sence of an expectant father to  
share with. When you get down to  
it, I, not we, was biologically  
pregnant. When the Third World and  
People's Park crises came, I stayed  
home to protect the unformed child  
inside me and David did battle in  
the streets.  

When I was seven months pregnant  
we moved into a house in Oakland  
with another couple and a single  
woman. We wanted to live communal-  
ly and literally took the plunge—  
barely knowing the other people.  
But dare to struggle, dare to win,  
and after all, we could always  
split if things didn't work out.  

About two weeks before the due  
date we waited in a time feeling  
that is very definitely one belong-  
ing to pregnancy—a feeling of days  
being epochs—a time feeling Doris  
Lessing captures so well in A Prop-  
er Marriage. At last labor began.  
It was slow and long. I spent a  
day at home and we kept saying, "Is  
it really happening now?"  

I was well trained in the pro-  
cess of natural or prepared child-  
birth, and David and I made a very  
good team of breather and coach/ti-  
mer. He was really there for me,  
helping me keep in control of the  
wave of each contraction. We are  
both excellent students and had  
learned our lessons well.  

The whole birth experience was  
one of joy and pain. It was a  
physical and emotional high unlike  
any I had ever experienced. "Pain  
and pushing and feeling relieved,"  
I wrote in my journal. David got  
tears in his eyes when I was final-  
ly dilated and started to push; I  
was totally involved in the physi-  
cal process with no energy to re-  
flect. How rare for me not to al-  
ways be watching and analyzing with  
my inner eye. David and I felt we  
were sharing a unique and loving  
moment.  

For many reasons the hospital  
stay was a downer. Mainly because  
immediately after the birth, I was  
separated from David. Once I knew  
Amanda was a girl who was perfectly  
formed physically, my main desires  
were to be with David and share our  
news with family and friends. But  
I was left alone in a crowded hos-  
pital. The nurses were hassled  
and bothered. I saw David three  
hours in total during the two days  
before I finally got rooming-in.  
After great protest and maneuvering  
I was put into rooming-in with  
three other women. Rooming-in  
means the babies and fathers are  
with you all day. My one night  
there I felt isolated from the oth-  
er women. They said things I  
couldn't identify with, which  
freaked me, like "I was my hus-  
band's bride, now I'm his son's  
mother." Discussions about endless  
shopping for the perfect crib and  
clothes went on. They told how  
being pregnant was their secret and  
how each decided the right moment  
to let her husband in on it. They  
each told their stories not really  
listening to the other women,  
waiting for the polite moment to  
relate their trip. I had enough  
consciousness then not to blame or  
put down those women. What this  
experience was for me, I wasn't  
sure; I was clearer about what it  
was not.  

to be continued...

LESBIAN 0010 YOU ?

I said I would write an article
about "Gay Women" for Big Mama and
since I happen to be one, (a Gay
Woman that is) I guess that's ap-
propriate. What does the word
Lesbian do to you? I know what it
used to do to me. It would bring
to mind imagery and words such as:
women in men's suits, perversion,
butch, insecurity and a threaten-
ing feeling. It still means that
for many people. Actually, the
word Lesbian has a long history.
The word stems from an old myth
about a group of very fierce Amazon
women who saw nothing wrong with
loving one another and developed
strong primary groups without men.
Their culture glorified women
loving women. These women lived
on the isle of Lesbos and from
there we get the derivative
"Lesbian."

Now to get to the concept of
Lesbian as it is for me and as
other people see me as a Lesbian.
A good many of the straight women
I know who used to be warm and
friendly have become cool and a-
loof, and as uninvolved as possible
now that they know I'm gay. I
think that I might raise some
doubts in their minds about their
life-styles and relationships with

men. I, also at some point, have
felt bisexuality intellectually to
be the ideal way for people to
exist, but on the reality level, I
feel that it's about as realistic
as asking for Utopia in Hell. I
also feel that sexuality labels
are degrading and limiting, but
are very necessary for the ways in
which people relate to each other
at this point. I personally can't
stand labels: heterosexual, bi-
sexual, homosexual. It shouldn't
make a difference but unfortunately
it does, and that's the situation
we're forced to deal with.

Men who see me as a Lesbian see
me as a challenge. Liberal men
want to get down to my basic human
spirit, and want me to prove to
them that I'm not really a castrat-
ing bitch. They're perfectly will-
ing to give me the chance. Fuck
it, if you'll pardon the expres-
sion, I'm tired of explaining my-
self to men. I'm tired of apolo-
gizing for feelings of anger, rage,
pain and hatred, that were placed
in me by men. I'm tired of ex-
plaining the dehumanizing destruc-
tion of my soul, my inner being,
me, to men who exclaim, "Well,
Honey, that wasn't me, that was
some other male chauvinist pig,"

or, "It's not me, it's the power
structure. I'm just a working
class pawn...true, I'm more privi-
leged than you, but honest I don't
have a God-Damned thing to do with
the mess women are in." The same
men will turn around and mess me
over on perhaps just a higher in-
tellectual level than the rest of
the Male Chauvinist Pigs. I've
finally decided that I have to
focus my anger on the people who
deserve it or destroy myself. The
battle is not over yet, and, by
God, I intend to win.

I enjoy determining who I am,
what I want, and I enjoy having
support from Lesbian sisters who
understand where I'm coming from,
recognize the enemy, and no longer
have to spout lies and make ex-
cuses for men. I enjoy loving and
being loved by women spiritually
and physically. I'm beginning to
think that Lesbians are the only
non-masochistic women in our so-
ciety. How can you conquer an op-
pressor when you sleep with him
every night? Yes, I did say con-
quer, the only way women are going
to obtain liberty is to take it.
As long as we relate to men and
they maintain positions of relative
power, we will continue to enforce
their positions in the status quo.
No oppressor readily relinquishes

power to pleading, and attempts at
education. It takes riots and
mass uprisings and strikes to hit
where it hurts, right in the balls
of male ruling class status quo
Capitalism. Every white man in
this country benefits from it, and
every woman, Chicano, Indian and
Black person suffers for it. How
long are we all going to let it

go on! Maureen Mrizek

In one sense it's the only

much younger than I, and yet
from a very selfish perspec-

I can share it with them. For

I am sure that when the real-

To those of you who

lective living on children,

PRESS ROOM

I asked myself why I was so enraged, and so profoundly embarrassed, by the photographs of the interior of the press room at the County Courthouse. I have seen pictures of nude women before, in what I consider to be degrading and humiliating poses. And I am

certainly no longer surprised to find instances of sexism in every aspect of our society. Why, then, does this example of overt male chauvinism affect me more deeply than some others? I think it is because of the specific circumstances—first, because it was in the county courthouse, a place where both men and women work all day, go in and out, etc. What does a woman feel who has to work in such an atmosphere? Secondly, these degrading photographs were in the press room, a place where people intimately involved with the media and news coverage work. It makes me cringe to think of what these men think of me, as a woman, and then to expand that to think of what the attitude of this country's media network is toward women in general. The same men who put up those pictures are the men who have, at their fingertips, access to the news media that can sway public opinion to a great degree. The tone and/or bias of their reporting can help to make or break the women's movement.

I ask myself why feminism is

Before and After

In doing political work, I have  
found myself in situations where it  
has always been very easy for me to  
remain passive—to prefer others,  
“especially men, to do the work that  
I was too insecure or self-  
conscious to do. I have always  
known "which side I was on," but I  
have not always been so sure of the  
reasons why. Never having had much  
practice at actually analyzing sit-  
uations myself, I was therefore  
very impressed (and intimidated) by  
people who could develop complex  
analyses and intellectualizations  
of different situations. This, of  
course, played right into my pas-  
sivity, my willingness to accept  
someone else's theory, my insecuri-  
ty in putting forward my own. Now,  
I am beginning to feel much better  
about myself and I have more confi-  
dence in my abilities to think, and  
this carries over into my relation-  
ships with others. I know that I  
have to PUSH myself to do those  
things that are important to do—  
to participate, to be active—even  
if I may feel terribly uncomfor-  
table and awkward. One of the most  
important factors in this is the  
support I get from my sisters.

Support Raises Consciousness

This support not only makes me  
strong enough to speak out in  
groups and contribute my opinions,  
but I find that it becomes easier  
to do the kind of reading and re-  
search necessary to enable me to  
raise my political consciousness to  
the point where I think it should  
be. It isn't hard anymore to admit  
my ignorance without shame, be-  
cause I know that I have the  
strength to do the self-education  
necessary to remedy that ignorance.  
I feel oftentimes that men are re-  
sentful of this kind of obvious  
strength. I understand that reac-  
tion, but it is only an example of  
the sexism which is in all of us.  
Most of us have learned to be  
threatened by people who are  
strong, who could be potential  
"competition."

These kinds of hostile, uptight  
reactions are balanced by the  
patronizing, "older brother" atti-  
tudes of some other movement men.  
It is almost as if they merely  
tolerate my sympathies with THEIR  
ideas—it makes me feel like a  
movement groupie. And it is an  
obvious indication that those men  
do not consider my political com-  

mitment and understanding to be any-  
where near as serious as their own.

This brings up a question which  
has been especially significant to  
me in dealing with "hip" or "move-  
ment" men: the question of integra-  
ting my sexuality with my intellect.  
I consider myself a political person,  
and also a sexual person. It has  
been possible for me a number of  
times to have truly meaningful rela-  
tionships with men—relationships in  
which little was hidden, thoughts  
were shared and expressed honestly—  
but these were rarely sexual rela-  
tionships. The most egalitarian ex-  
periences I have had with men were  
not physical at all. And in the  

same way, the sexual relationships I  
have had with men were rarely able  
to develop into anything deeper  
without being extremely sexist—in  
other words, my role in the rela-  
tionship had already been defined in  
a purely sexual way. So, a problem  
arises—in order to keep myself out  
of exploitive situations, I find  
myself continually denying my sexu-  
ality—negating my womanhood in or-  

der to function effectively with men.

I ignore my physical feelings as  
best I can—I have consciously de-  
cided that it is actually safer and  
much less hassle to avoid sexual re-  
lationships with men, at least for  
the time being.

People Change Slowly

I understand that people change  
slowly, and that's why I'm waiting  
and struggling with the people I  
love. But it also makes me very  
angry to constantly try to act dif-  
ferently than I feel—to be unable  
to really be the warm, open person I  
know I can be, because I know people  
don't understand that in the way  
that I mean it. So, I have to be  
cautious. It just isn't worth it  
anymore to make love with a man and  
have it end up the way it usually  
does—with a huge space between us  
afterwards—the cold feeling when I  
realize that suddenly the prelimin-  
ary closeness, the meaningful talk  
is over, because he's finally  

fucked me. And all of the mech-  
anisms I use to keep myself from  
dwelling on the shittiness of it  
all, my rationalizations, my over-  
looking of things he said and did—  
they don't work anymore. I like my-  
self too much now—I respect myself  
and care for myself and I WON'T LET  
IT HAPPEN ANYMORE! So, for now, al-  
though I will work on building hon-  
est relationships with men, I must  
be sure that the sexual aspect is  

as honest as the intellectual.

This brings up another question  
which I have done a lot of thinking  
about recently—that of bisexuality  
or gay relationships. As I become  
more conscious of my womanhood, it  
becomes more difficult for me to  
submit myself to a heterosexual re-  
lationship in which I am uncomfor-  
table or in which I see even the  
most subtle sexist patterns. But  
at the same time, my need for sex-  
ual contact, my sexual frustration,  
continues. And I find that the  
only people I can completely trust  
are the few women I have come to  
love. Because I know that they  
are honestly struggling with their  
sexuality and that they consider  
dealing with sexism (in themselves  
as well as in others) as an ongo-  

ing process that must be integra-  
ted into their everyday existence.  
So it becomes increasingly easy  
for me to think of making love to  
a woman—in fact, that doesn't  
seem at all threatening compared  
to becoming sexually involved with  
a man. It's quite a change for  
me. Until recently I hadn't even  
considered bisexuality, and now in  
many ways it is much more attrac-  
tive than heterosexuality. I'm  
not saying I will cease to be at-  
tracted to men, not at all; just  
that I am now feeling comfortable  
about physical relationships with  
women also.

So what does all this mean? I  
cannot at all see myself with-  
drawing from men completely. I  
live with men, my political work  
must necessarily involve and in-  
clude men. There are a few men  
whom I truly love and trust to a  
large degree. But I know that  
all men—and women too—have a  
thousand subtle, deep-seated  
feelings about each other—  
feelings that we cannot even iden-  
tify, that color our actions in  
ways we haven't even imagined.

And I feel that these feelings op-  
erate most strongly and subcon-  
sciously in those situations that  
are based in emotions and in those  
situations in which we have had  
the least practice at being open  
and honest. Sexual matters are  
the perfect examples of this.

Our society has taught us to be se-  
cretive and non-communicative  
about sex, let alone being embar-  
rassed and ashamed. We cannot  
talk to each other or learn from  
each other. We come together in  
bed and operate from two separate  
points—apart. How can we expect  

to communicate at that stage of the  
game, without any real preliminary  
honesty that deals specifically  
with sex? What I mean is that 99%  
of the time, men whom I sleep with  
are bound to be operating from a  
self-centered position—and nec-  
essarily so—because we probably  
have not been able to deal effec-  
tively with all of the quiet pri-  
vate thoughts, fears, and hang-ups  
we each have about our bodies and  
sex. So, men (and women, too) in  

a sexual relationship will be ac-  
ting out a lot of emotional, large-  
ly irrational responses. Where in-  
tellectually, many people can  
recognize and struggle with sexist  
feelings, in a sexual relationship,  
which is largely emotional, this  
might not be possible.

I am by no means advocating the  
increased intellectualization of  
personal relationships. I am an  
emotional person. What I mean is  
that we must really try to under-  
stand our emotions, our spontaneous  
responses to situations and people.  
And this is very hard—much more  
difficult than changing one's mind  
about a political matter or an in-  
tellectual decision. It goes to  
the very root of how we function as  
human beings, and how we relate to  
others. This is what I see as the  
true struggle—the radical struggle—  
the willingness to examine and deal  
with those very things that govern  
our every moment of existence. 13

determination, real control over one's

describes the hell she underwent in
being forcibly rehabilitated. Esther

years of forced compliance Sylvia did

Ms. Emory was one of the 315

she did not sit back and view her

University of Colorado Medical
School.

The suit came to trial in the Fall

presiding, with Martin P. Miller
representing Ms. Emory in the suit.

Two months later Judge Johns

His verdict echoed almost
word for word C.U.’s Defense Stat-
istics and Logic used in the trial.
He admitted that women are under-
represented in Medical Schools,

a better representation of women
than most schools.

Angela (another B.M.R. reporter)

ing the trial. She had several things

Med. School made of the "Equal
Rejection Theory." The "Equal Rejec-
tion Theory" was used through the
courts for many years; it was used

racial minorities. Most courts today

racial discrimination.

separating the number of applicants

white, male, female. C.U. Med.
School separates their applicants in-
to groups of male and female. The
figures they use are the percentage of
applicants accepted from each group.

2,524 male applicants, 107 were accep-
ted, a percentage of 4.24 acceptance
of male applicants. Out of 333 female
applicants, 18 were accepted, a per-
centage of 5.4 of the total female
applicants.

When the class make-up is viewed
in this manner, the real class make-

obscured.

WRITE WOMEN BACK

"From the dawn of civil-
ization women have made
important contributions
to society. And, under

the heel of oppression,

women have struggled for
freedom. In asserting
the right of women, we
reclaim our heritage...
Write women back into
history."

A proud and angry statement
that makes you want to run out
and discover your past, isn't
it? It is from a series of
posters of famous women in his-
tory that the Young Socialist
Alliance is producing. I have
put up in my study the intro-
ductory statement and four of
the posters, for inspiration.

Much as I like this series,
however, I sometimes have
trouble with the second state-
ment. First, it tends to mis-
lead us into thinking of women's
history as always, everywhere
the same: women's history e-
quals oppression. Second, we
have to be careful in looking
for antecedents to our own
struggle. Women's "struggle for
freedom" did not occur as fre-
quently nor in all the places
one might expect.

For example, the history of
17th and early 18th century wo-
men, particularly the Protestant
women of English descent, should
be approached on its own terms.
If it is forced into the 19th
and 20th century categories of
oppression and liberation, we
only confuse ourselves.

Let us look at the 17th and
early 18th century women. What
exactly would oppression have
meant for these colonial women?
Certainly the attitudes ex-
pressed by literate men about
women left something to be de-
sired. Woman, according to a
very long tradition, was a weak
creature. She was, first, men-
tally weak. Overtaking her
brain by excessive reading and
writing might well unhinge her
mind. This was a pity, but, of
course, she couldn't be blamed
for her inferiority. But there
was a second kind of female
weakness which the early colon-
ial men found positively dis-
concerting. Woman was the
daughter of Eve, and she in-
herited her mother's moral weak-
ness. Worse, like Eve, she had
a seductive power that could
pull men down with her. Al-
though this image of woman as
“the dangerous sex" was usually
latent, it occasionally sur-
faced as it did in the Salem
witch trials. It was because
of these weaknesses, finally,
that woman was subordinate,
subordinate to her father in
childhood and later to her hus-
band in marriage.

But what did all this intel-
lectualizing actually mean in
the lives of colonial women?

INTO HISTORY

To begin with, the average co-
lonial woman was not well edu-
cated. Most girls who were
educated at all were taught the
rudiments at home or in the sum-
mer sessions of the public
schools if they existed. Even
in Massachusetts, a colony with
a considerable concern for edu-
cation, only 50% of the women
could sign their own names in
the mid 17th century. But how
significant was this depriva-
tion in a society in which edu-
cation was not necessary for
survival and in which most men
were equally deprived? Lack of
educational opportunities did
not mean to the colonial woman
what it would mean to us.

Under English common law in
which woman was declared civil-
ly dead at marriage, woman's
legal status looks oppressive.
However, in America, the harsh-
ness of English law was modi-
fied by Equity law: if a woman
came into a marriage with con-
siderable property of her own

her father would make out a
contract to protect her right
to this property. The law as
practiced protected her rights
in her husband's property. Di-
vorce was permitted when either
party to a marriage could prove
that the other had neglected a
fundamental duty.

The fact that English law
was modified in the American
colonies is significant. Wo-
men were in short supply in
the early period. Companies
who invested in a colony real-
ized how important the pre-
sence of women was to the cre-
ation of a permanent colony
and made efforts to induce wo-
men into coming to the New
World. The London Co. which
underwrote the Virginia colony
advertised for “Agreeable per-
sons, young and incorrupt...
(who would be) sold with their
own consent to settlers as
wives, the price to be the
cost of their own transporta-
tion." Apparently women
found this offer very attrac-
tive. In 1619 ninety came on
one ship alone. Historians
have speculated that it was in
part this demand for women that
made women's place in colonial
American society much better
than that of their sisters who
remained in the Mother Country.

But even if they had been in
good supply, the work of the
early colonial women, even wo-
men of the wealthier classes,
made them absolutely indispen-
sable. From earliest childhood
when a girl began doing house-
hold and barnyard chores the
female was a useful and pro-
ductive member of her family.
In her early to mid-twenties,
she married and bore on the
average nine to ten children.
Childbearing was hard and the
mother's life expectancy was
7 years less than her husband's.
Two or three of those children
died before they were adults.
Aside from childbearing and
rearing, she was in charge of
the home. It was not the con-
suming home of the 19th century
but the producing home, a small
manufacturing unit which turned
raw materials that the husband
produced—grains, flax, leather,
meat—into usable products.

The woman and her daughter made
all the cloth for the family,
turned the cloth into clothing,
did all the brewing, baking,
and curing of meat. They made
wax and the only form of light-
ing, candles; they made the
family soap out of drippings
and lye, the lye from ashes.
The woman had charge of the fam-
ily garden and of the family
doctoring. It was an extremely
difficult life but through her
work she had the self-respect
and the community respect that

cont. on page 5

—————————————————e—

society denied to her 19th cen-
tury sister, the middle class
lady of leisure.

While the majority of women
did essential, respected work
in the home, there was an in-
teresting minority of women who
worked outside the home. "They
were butchers, silversmiths,
gunsmiths and upholsterers.

They ran mills, tanneries, ship-
yards and every kind of shop,
tavern and boarding house. They
were gatekeepers, jail keepers,
sextons, journalists, printers,
doctoresses, apothecaries, mid-
wives, nurses and teachers."
This comes as a surprise because
we usually think of women’s work
outside the home and in the pro-
fessions coming in the 19th cen-
tury, after a long and bitter
struggle. Apparently, however,
the prejudice against middle
class women working outside

the home, the horror with

which men heard women's de-
mands to be something more

than just wives and mothers,

was an idea that emerged not
early, but late, with the

growth of wealth and the bour-
geois culture of the late 18th
and 19th centuries.

So we come back to the ori-
ginal question, can we call
these conditions under which
colonial women lived, oppres-
sive to women as women? The
evidence of the oppression of
women per se is far from over-
whelming.

But sometimes we do find a
woman who was dissatisfied with
her position as a woman. I
wonder sometimes how Anne
Hutchinson, an early religious
rebel who ran intellectual cir-
cles around the governor of
Massachusetts Bay colony at her
trial, felt about the charge
that headed the list of com-
plaints against her, that she
had inspired other women to be
"rather...a Husband than a
Wife." We have no evidence
that Mistress Hutchinson was
anything but a religious rebel
but we have a little in the
case of another Anne. Anne

Bradstreet came to the American
colonies in 1630 as the bride
of an early governor of Massa-
chusetts. She was a poet, one
of the earliest in the English
colonies. Her poems run the
gamut from long philosophical
ones like "The Flesh and the
Spirit" to love poems written
to her "dear and loving hus-
band."
If ever two were one,
then surely we.
If ever man were loved
by wife, then thee...
But as happy as Anne was with
her marriage, she occasionally
spoke out against a society
that refused to take her intel-
lectual work seriously.
I am obnoxious to
each carping tongue
Who says my hand a
needle better fits,
A poet's pen all scorn
I should thus wrong,
For such despite they cast
on female wit:
If what I do prove well,
it won't advance,
They'll say it's stol'n,
or else it was by chance.
Despite the two Annes how-
ever, I think the evidence suc-
gests that given the frontier
conditions of the early colon-
ies in which life was equally
hard for both men and women,
and where women's work was as
vital and as respected as that
of the ordinary man's, great
debates about the essential e-
quality or inferiority of women
probably seemed to most people,
men and women alike, somewhat
irrelevant. A movement of op-
pressed women awaited a revolu-
tionary ideology of equality
and, at least as important, the
change of status forced on women
by the new industrial society
of the 19th century.

The Mountain States Women's Abortion Coalition (MSWAC) held a "Crimes Against Women Tribunal" on Saturday, November 11, at the CU Denver Center Auditorium. The purpose of the event was to present personal testimony of women who have had difficult experiences regarding abortions, birth control information, rape, welfare and health departments, and all areas of female oppression. Another purpose of the Tribunal was to publicly demonstrate that incidents of women's oppression are not isolated—that many, many women have experiences of this kind.

These are some of the comments made by participants:

"In Utah a person cannot get contraceptive help if she is under 18 without parental consent. I got pregnant when I was 16. My parents are middle-class Catholics and I'd always been taught that abortion was murder. They sent me to a priest for advice. Apparently, when your mother is the president of the Parish's Catholic Women's Club, abortion is OK. He suggested that I get an abortion."

A psychiatric nurse pointed out that "repeal of all abortion laws would be great, but then there would be problems with Denver's medical community, which is very conservative and would probably stop doing abortions altogether if there were no laws to protect them."

The Chairwoman stressed the need to ask for "more than we hope to get."

Attorney Sandy Nemser discussed prostitution as a class issue based on the distinction between call girls and whores. Referring to the then upcoming election, Nemser quoted Gloria Steinem: "If McGovern got pregnant, he'd come to some sort of decision about what to do about it. If Nixon got pregnant, he'd go ahead and get an abortion, deny it, and swear he was a virgin."

The Chairwoman announced that folksinger Judy Collins had planned to testify at the Tribunal but was unable to attend at the last minute. Collins made the point that she did not want to sing, but just to say how she felt.

Pat Schroeder, at that time campaigning for Congress from the First Congressional District, spoke openly about a woman's right to control her own body. She pointed out that Congress has given priority to heart and cancer research, but that birth control and reproductive research have not been as important to Congress. She then pointed out that only 12 out of 435 members of Congress are women.

A young woman from Fort Worth, Texas, said that she had made the decision not to have children and that as a heterosexual saw her choices as "(1) Taking a pill a day for thirty years, (2) having a series of abortions, or (3) getting a tubal ligation." She tried to get a tubal ligation, but "no doctor in the phone book of Fort Worth would give me one because they didn't think I needed one."

The Chairwoman introduced a gay woman from Boulder as "wanting to speak to express solidarity with us and our problems," to which the speaker replied, "Solidarity is not the question, because we're all women." She went on to discuss the health dangers of contraceptive pills and to offer some suggestions in dealing with rapists.

A female lawyer from Legal Aid remarked, "What I've learned (in working at Legal Aid) is that women are victims and see themselves as victims, especially poor women."

An attorney from the National Lawyers' Guild said: "Abortion really is a class problem because it was never a problem with a rich woman... you could always go to San Juan." He went on to quote Tolstoy: "'The rich will do anything for the poor, except get off their backs.' The same goes for men and women."

LIBERATION BEGINS

One evening in Venice, Cali-
fornia a couple of years ago a
friend and I, in a fit of bour-
geois debauchery, sat drinking
Scotch and water over a hand of
rummy. I was keeping up a pat-
ter of light conversation to
hide the fact that I was losing
the game. The light conversa-
tion being the women's movement.
My friend was basically a cynic
and I was into the revolution:
down with the ruling class (the
rich) and worry about petty de-
tails like the alleged oppres-
sion of women later. Not want-
ing to be accused of turning on
my own people I always gave a
polite interest to the rising
fury of women, but frankly I
felt that it was an unnecessary
factionalization of the radical
movement (whatever that was).
Actually what was happening was
that I was getting my political
analysis from the circle of male
politicos, well-read and arti-
culate, that made up many of my
close friends at that time.

So anyhow, over the Scotch,
Joyce and I sat talking. "You
know," sez I, being just as cute
as hell, “some of my best friends
are men." We kicked that around
for a while. We came to the con-
clusion that even worse than that
(and, it's true) is that few of
my best friends at that time were
women. I began to consider that
maybe it wasn't some kind of ac-
cident that most of the women I
knew were as boring as hell:
never activating anything on
their own, but existed only in
their relationship to some guy
somewhere, like my boyfriend
this or that. It is pretty hard
to gain valuable companionship
from a person who ain't even
there. Many things, thoughts
that had been laying dormant in
the back of my mind came into
being that evening. Mostly they
concerned my own identity: not
exactly who I was, but definitely
who I was not.

I was in love with James Dean.

Through the course of our con-
