THE FOLLOWING IS A REPORT AND ANALYSIS OF AN INTERVIEW WHICH PAT SCHROEDER, RECENTLY
ELECTED DENVER CONGRESSWOMAN, GRANTED TWO STAFF MEMBERS FROM BIG MAMA RAG, J. BRYSON
AND M. WATERS. 

WE FEEL THAT CRITICIZING THE WOMAN'S IDEAS SERIOUSLY MEANS THAT WE TAKE THAT FOR OURSELVES.

THE WOMEN'S MOVEMENT WILL GROW STRONGER ONLY BY CAREFULLY EXAMINING WHAT WE ARE DOING POLITICALLY.

Pat Schroeder's campaign slogan read, "She wins. We win." But did we, the women who are her constituents, really win? A recent interview with the Denver Congresswoman-elect raises some interesting questions.

For example, when asked where she stood on women's issues, Ms. Schroeder replied, "You know, I don't have any problems with that at all. The whole campaign was still run as a humanist campaign. It seems to me that I'm not pushing for men, I'm not pushing for women. I'm not pushing for children. We're pushing for people, and that's what the whole darn thing's about. . . Everybody wants a fair crack at it without looking at whether they're male, female, black, brown, old, young. . .

Furthermore, in responding to a question dealing with what kinds of specific legislation Ms. Schroeder plans to work for while in Congress, she cited at least seven different concerns without so much as mentioning even one issue which deals directly with the problems of women as women in this country today. (Abortion, child care, job discrimination, etc.)

Listed under "New Directions, '72-'76," the Democratic Platform states, "We are determined to remove barriers that limit citizens because they are black, brown, young, or women; because they never had the chance to gain an education; because there was no possibility of being anything but what they were." Although Ms. Schroeder's stands are certainly in line with this ideal, that is all it is--an ideal. In other words, it is of primary importance at this particular time in history for minority groups and women to identify themselves as such first. Of course we are all working ultimately for human liberation, but if we spread ourselves as thinly as cheap mayonnaise over too many causes, we may end up with only an ineffectual thin coating of liberality.

When approached on this point--that certain groups (particularly women) must work for their own rights first, Schroeder had this to say, "Sure it's important for women to seek an identity and I'm not putting that down at all. But I'm also saying that you can't just do that to the exclusion of everything else."

BMR: "To be successful in politics, you mean?”

SCHROEDER: "I don’t even think — that's it. I just don't believe in any one issue. I'm also concerned about peace. If I had to pick one thing, it would probably be peace--defense spending, Armed Forces, environment. . . Those are equally as important. If I stood up and said that I'm primarily concerned about women's rights, I'd be lying. I'm very concerned about women's rights, but no more so than I'm concerned about peace, environment. . .

THIS ANALYSIS IS A CRITICAL ONE. NO ONE SPEAKS FOR US. IDEAS OF ANOTHER WOMAN IS NOT OPPOSED TO SISTERHOOD.

And I just don't believe in getting hung-up on one issue. I find the world is full of one-issue people. They've got tunnel vision."

This all sounds very convincing, of course. I mean, who would dare say that anything was more important than peace? The fact remains, however, that women have been railroaded by this line of reasoning since the first voices were raised in protest. "Let's get to the most important things first and then we'll work on your problems," say the liberal male politicians and others. That's just another side-stepping tactic to keep us quiet and in "our places." Naturally, we are all concerned about peace and the environment as well as many other current issues, but how can we as women always work effectively for those issues when our very effectiveness is already limited by the fact that we are women.

Bella Abzug, the N.Y. Congresswoman is involved with many contemporary problems, but women's issues are usually a priority. Similarly, Ron Dellums, the black Congressman from California is working for a great number of issues but black concerns are of the utmost importance. That kind of identification is not a display of “tunnel vision" or of “one-issue candidacy." Ms. Abzug, Mr. Dellums, and others know who they are and just what it is they stand for.

When Pat Schroeder was asked how she came to be identified as a liberal congresswoman, she said, "Well, I've never really identified myself as anything. I think so often you end up getting into a psychological briar patch. . . And I've tried never to really identify with anything that way." And responding to a question asking whether she considered herself to be a feminist, Ms. Schroeder replied, "Oh, I've always identified myself as a woman. Let me back up. To some extent I've never really liked, like the Women's Division of the Bar because I've always figured that men and women practice law the same. It's ridiculous. It should be an integrated bar. Theoretically, we all do the same thing. In law school once, they said, ‘Would you teach a course in women's legal rights?' And I said, ‘Well, no one's teaching one in male's legal rights.' What I think they should do is a bigger picture in, let's say, discrimination. Do the whole thing. . . Don't just do women, don't just do blacks, not just Indians. And I think that's the focus you have to keep on. I've never tried to hide the fact that I'm a woman. I think that any kind of sex discrimination is just awful. I'm not one of those women who say, ‘Gee, I've never found that.' Because I certainly found it everywhere I.

Dear People,

It's been emphasized that as women we ought to learn how to really communicate and thus cease viewing each other as threats. However, women are one part of the whole. The truth is, people are not communicating with people.

This capitalistic society possesses a unique way of keeping us humans alienated. It's called "competition."

Most women only see other women as competitors because they define themselves in terms of "beauty" (society's conception of what beauty is — blond, 36 bust, etc.), wealth and status.

However, men aren't relating for the same basic reasons. And one can't view another as a potential friend if one's worried about whether the poor dude is outdoing you. "He's fucked more chicks than I, He's sexier. His penis is bigger. He makes 10 grand, I make 8. I've only got a Mustang and he's got a Porsche."

It's really time to stop evaluating our beings in terms of the outside standards of beauty, wealth and status. When we realize our capacity as humans for such forsaken emotions as compassion, love (not sex) and understanding, we can afford to halt competition.

When this is ended we can realize that our sisters and brothers are not mere obstacles on some road to success who we must beat out or get ahead of. Perhaps then we can see each other as humans with emotional needs and finally reach out and embrace each other instead of crushing one another. Relating to women and men will only come after redefining our goals and worths in terms of humanity.

mental health for over two years
now. Though I have many criti-
cisms of and disagreements with
frequent practices and attitudes
in the field, I will restrict
this discussion to women—and
how their (our) position in this
society is constantly reinforced
by therapists.

I shall cite a few specific
examples of what I am talking
about.

A behavior modification pro-
gram is designed for a female
patient. Among the expected be-
haviors (for which she will earn
such "privileges" as eating,
smoking cigarettes, going on an
outing) are hair setting, bed-
making and wearing make-up. Is
hair setting truly an indication
of a well-functioning woman?
Perhaps to these therapists. Or
wearing make-up? I do neither
and haven't for years, and con-
sider myself a well-functioning
woman. And what about making
one's bed? That's another thing
I seldom do, and many of my
friends seldom do. Our defini-
tions of sick and healthy, nor-
mal and abnormal behavior, feel-
ings and needs, must be changed.

Another woman, perhaps be-
tween the ages of 17 and 25, en-
ters a hospital in a "post-par-
tum psychotic episode". This is
the label assigned a woman who
becomes depressed immediately
after giving birth. She may
stop eating, stop talking, and
perhaps even reject the child
she has just birthed. Is this
truly sick? Perhaps she is de-
pressed because she suddenly
realized that her schooling will
end, or that her career is over.

Or that she is now, for the next
15 years or so, responsible for
another human being. Responsible
for her/his health, both physical
and mental. Perhaps she recog-
nizes that her life is no longer
her own, that she is expected to
dedicate it to another human
being, and pretty much ignore her
own needs and longings. And
what if she doesn't want to do
this? Then she is made to feel
guilty by those around her. Made
to feel she is inadequate as a
woman, as a human being. Women
are not expected to spend their
lives pursuing their own goals.
They are expected to have as
their primary goal dedication to
another, or two or three (hus-
band, children) human beings. A
woman in post-partum depression
is usually convinced by her ther-
apist, and perhaps her loved
ones (as well as other patients)
that it is "sick" of her to have
become depressed. That being a
mother is the ultimate experience
a woman can have. And perhaps so,
for some women. But I suspect
that if more options were truly
open to us, more and more women
would choose not to become
mothers—ever. I suspect that were
the burden of child-rearing shifted,
either severally or collectively,
that the rate of post-partum
psychosis would decrease.

An older woman, perhaps 55,
enters the hospital in deep de-
pression. Her diagnosis is in-
volutional melancholia. Involu-
tional melancholia is described
as being distinguished from psy-
chotic depressive reaction in that
the depression "is not due to some
life experience". Perhaps being a
woman and growing old in this
society is not considered enough
of a "life experience" to cause
depression. Perhaps having
completed one's positive role in
this society, as sex object and
mother, should not cause a woman
to become depressed. But if a
woman grows up thinking, as most
women in America do, that her
worth, her significance as a
human being, depends on her youth,
beauty and charm (her sexual at-
tractiveness) and her function as
mother, then certainly when she
loses these roles we shouldn't be
surprised that she is depressed.
Nor should we consider her de-
pression a problem. It is a
problem created by the arbitrary
expectations placed on women in
this society—that they devote
their energies to the children
and husband, and that they remain
young. Their depression is valid
and understandable.

And I hope and ache that the
depression changes to anger which
she will direct where it belongs—
not on herself, but on the sys-
tem. And how is such a woman
treated? Few therapists are in
touch with, let alone point out
to such a patient, that it is not
she who is "sick", but the soci-
ety. Few therapists recognize
that it is a sick society that
permits people to feel worthless
at age 50, or thinks it healthy
that a human being live her life
vicariously through her husband
and children, or that she be sub-
servient for most of her adult
life. What frequently happens is
that the woman is given electro-
convulsive therapy—shock therapy
to the layperson. Or she is
placed on anti-depressants and
put in a therapy group where she
is counseled that her life is
not over, and it's silly for her
to think it is, or for her to
want to end it.

Would you want to end yours?
Have you known anyone who has or
has wanted to? Were you able to
get in touch with why? I can.
And it makes my blood boil to
know that most women today will
be depressed, either mildly or
severely, and consider it "their
problem" and even feel guilty
for needing care and being un-
able to cook and clean for their
husbands because of their depres-
sion. It makes me angry to know
that it will be years before this
changes. Years before male
therapists start to really under-
stand what it is like to be a
woman in this society. Years to be
aware of their own per-

sonal oppression as women, in
all its subtle manifestations—

Most books written for chil-
dren are insidious perpetuators
of a crippling status quo.
Looking back over our own
childhood favorites, we were
disconcerted to find that we
were exposed to a rather narrow
range of life experiences and
roles in literature. Remember
Nancy (WASP) Drew, whose blond
hair flew in the wind as she
rushed from mystery to mystery
in her brand new sports coupe?
And Peter Pan, surrounded by
sexy little Tinkerbelle and the
capable Wendy, and who never
has to grow up and deal with
growing relationships with real
and mature people?

We want children to have a
broader range of reading avail-
able to them - books that offer
alternative values and models
for new ways of functioning.

We must encourage our children
to develop thoughtful analyses
of the printed word from a
very early age, in order that
they may emerge stronger and
more perceptive from exposure
to the abundance of bad books
designed for them.

CENSORSHIP

Censorship robs a child of
a variety of reading experiences,
both good and bad, and denies
the child a chance to develop
his/her discriminatory powers.
However, unless he/she is exposed
to alternatives to prevailing
limits of sex-class-race-age
stereotyping, it will be hard
for any child to see a way out
of the confinement of life
situations presented in tradi-
tional childhood reading
material.

CRITERIA

We set out to explore the
available market in children's
literature. Very few books,
we found, could satisfy our
criteria - that they be non-sex-
ist, non-racist, and non-condes-
cending to young readers - in
other words, that they be
non-chauvinistic in every sense.
Even fewer were interesting,
well-written, or reasonably
priced.

LITTLE MISS MUFFET FIGHTS BACK

The trend in books for little
children is to present very
beautiful, adult-aimed illustra-
tions, accompanied by inane text,

After a year of consciousness-raising and unfocused political actions, our group decided to direct its energies towards the Women's Health Movement, which we feel has real revolutionary implications for the whole Feminist Movement. Women have lost the power we once had over our own bodies and been forced into dependency on a male-controlled medical profession motivated by profit. There was a time when women were responsible for the health care of their own families and households and midwives responsible for all gynecological and obstetrical care. Reclaiming control of our bodies from the medical industry, Madison Avenue, and big business is a basic step in gaining control of our lives.

Three women in our group traveled to Los Angeles and San Francisco about the same time and gleaned some information from the women's centers about what was happening in women's health. One of these women went back to L.A. and attended a self-health course which met weekly. She learned the simple procedures; she brought back the experience, some literature, and a dozen speculums; and Colorado Springs had its first self-health session that week. We found that our fears and self-consciousness vanished almost at once with the excitement that came with the first real knowledge about our bodies.

We realized why physicians have been reluctant to share their information ($$$) and, more important, we realized we were making a reality out of the slogan "Control of our own bodies."

We have found that what works most effectively for us is to have three sessions with each small group of women (about 6-8 has been maximum). Our first session always begins with a "rap time" when many fears, misconceptions, resentments, and experiences about things like sex, reproduction, and physiology are shared. We find in sharing our experiences that each woman has at some point in her life been mistreated by physicians, and for many it has been a general rule.

One woman we know, having suffered severe cramps for several months, went to her doctor to have her Dalkon shield (IUD) removed. She learned that the device had slipped and that her cervix had dilated. She had been having labor pains for months! (She was led to believe that discomfort was normal in using an IUD.) The irony is that because she knew the cervix would have to be dilated for removal of the device, and because she wanted a non-messy, constant means of birth control besides the pill, she had it removed only as a last resort. Had she been participating in self-health and examining herself on a regular basis, she would have known there was a real problem and would have gone much sooner for help.

Each woman at the first session purchases a packet made up of good factual literature, her own speculum, and the other necessary supplies for self-examination. There are always at least two women present who have been through the recommended three sessions and feel confident about the procedures. These two women demonstrate to the group how to use the speculum and how to give bi-manual (two hands) pelvic examinations and then invite each woman to participate. If for any reason a woman prefers not to take part, of course she needn't do so. So far every woman has been eager for her turn. Seeing your cervix for the first time is a mind-blow! The mystery is gone, and you gain a new liking for your own body.

In the second session most of our anxiety and self-consciousness is gone. We are able to notice more in our examinations (what is a "tipped uterus"? what are the differences in the cervix of a woman who has had children and one who has not? what are the normal changes in color, shape, and size of the cervix?) Rap-time might be discussing the written material distributed the previous week, or any other subject of interest; we have much to learn from each other.

Either the second or third session is a good time to learn breast self-examination, using the step-by-step procedures explained in a handout sheet.

By the third session, women are usually turned on to the political implications of self-health and to the fact that getting to know ourselves may save our lives. We've been killing ourselves with panic abortion methods, going without PAP smears, etc. We hope that women will continue examining themselves on a regular basis from now on. And now many of these women are ready to start new groups, which is how the movement spreads.

The week of October 11-14th a National Self-Health Conference was held in Iowa City in which women from all over the U.S. and even Canada got together to share their questions and knowledge about women's health. We have divided into geographic regions in order to spread self-health to all our sisters in the quickest and most effective way. Women of our region were present from Colorado Springs, Nebraska, and Utah, and we plan to reach out to other states in the coming months.

Women from Self-Health Clinic I in California (the Feminist Women's Health Center in L.A.) were the originators of the national conference and gave us ideas from their own experience over the past two years. We learned skills, saw films, attended workshops, and generally got turned on to the potential of the women's health movement.

We in Colorado Springs are hoping soon to start work in abortion counseling and referral, wider self-health reach-out (to non-feminist women's groups, for example), patient advocacy (i.e. going along with sisters to doctors, hospitals, etc., demanding information, observation, and high standards), and eventually even opening a women's clinic. We have, in effect, become a women's health collective.

Although we have found one supportive doctor, most physicians are threatened by this movement, and we see several reasons for it. First, of course, they are afraid we'll stop coming to them entirely and they'll no longer get our money. For the most part this isn't true, since one of the main results of self-health is that we get women who show some signs of abnormality to go to a doctor sooner than they might usually go, but equipped with more useful information than they might normally have. A woman in a recent self-health class (her first session) had what the more experienced women immediately felt to be an inflammation of the cervix (bright red instead of pink). She was being treated for a bladder infection by a doctor, but had not been examined internally. (Her medication was not reducing pain, incidentally). So with a sister for support, she went to her doctor again the following...

On January 22 the U.S. Supreme Court ruled 7-2 that in the first three months of pregnancy the decision of whether to have an abortion is between a woman and her doctor; in the next six months, the state may regulate the abortion procedure in ways that reasonably relate to maternal health. Only in the last 10 weeks may a state ban abortions except where they are necessary to preserve the woman's life or health.

The decision firmly recognizes a woman's right to control her own body as a part of her fundamental right to privacy, and was seen as a victory for the women's movement.

Not until March 5, however, did the Colorado Supreme Court, basing its ruling on the January decision, strike down the state abortion law's restrictions as unconstitutional. The Colorado law, which previously had been considered "liberal," contained certain "requirements" which the U.S. Supreme Court specifically stated were unconstitutional, namely, 1) that there be a residency requirement; 2) that abortions be performed in hospitals accredited by a private agency; 3) that applicants be screened by a hospital committee; or 4) that independent doctors certify the potential dangers of a pregnancy to a woman's physical or mental health.

In addition, the Colorado decision guaranteed the civil rights of those hospital employees who refuse to participate in abortion procedures by stating that such refusal may not be a basis for any disciplinary action against that employee. The decision also stated that any hospital can refuse to admit a patient for an abortion.

Denver citizens demonstrate at a recent abortion rally.

According to members of the Mountain States Women's Abortion Coalition (MSWAC), which has been investigating the implementation of the new rulings in local hospitals, most hospitals are changing or have changed their procedures to comply with the ruling. Some of those hospitals providing abortions without restriction during the first trimester are General Rose, Beth Israel, Denver General, and Colorado General.

On March 12 the U.S. Supreme Court, ruling on the Illinois abortion law, and declaring it unconstitutional, concurrently issued an order that all state governments must comply with the original January decision and will no longer be allowed to procrastinate in creating new laws.

"One thing I'm worried about," said Nancy Stern, a lawyer for the Center for Constitutional Rights, commenting on the January 22 decision, "is that women will now say, ‘OK, it's all over. Now I can get an abortion if I want one and that's that.' But there's a real possibility that a state pressured by anti-abortion forces will pass abortion laws, under the guise of protecting a woman's health, which will actually succeed in restricting her right to an abortion."

BMIR Editorial

by Bourge Miller

“While the January 22 Supreme Court decision concerning abortion brought welcome and hard-fought-for relief to millions of Americans, concerned women must face the reality that the decision is not at all the total victory sought in the fight to control our own reproductive lives. Rather, it is only the first step, although a very meaningful one, in that direction. The ruling has removed many barriers, but has left or erected others.

Some painful issues still pending and some points to be vitally aware of are these:

1) The ruling places no restrictions on abortion during the first trimester, except the requirement that it be performed by a licensed physician. However, beginning with the second trimester, states are still free to regulate abortion procedures "in ways that are reasonably related to maternal health." Legislative action in this area must be carefully monitored to ensure continued protection of our rights.

2) The Supreme Court ruling makes no reference to the age at which a woman may obtain an abortion. Legislation will most certainly take place in this area. Must our younger sisters still face the red tape of parental or spousal consent? Do these women not also have the right to privacy as guaranteed by the Constitution?

3) Although the high court has just recently issued an additional order directing states to bring themselves into full compliance with the new ruling, it is clear that some state legislatures, state attorneys general, hospitals, etc. will most certainly attempt to impede the implementation of the decision. Those in the abortion rights movement must continue to press for speedy implementation of the ruling until all have complied.

4) "Right-to-Life" forces have responded to the ruling with moralistic indignation and irrelevant appeals to emotionalism that do not deal with the constitutional issues at hand. They have also introduced two bills into Congress (See page 8 - this issue).

5) It is extremely important to note that the ruling leaves open a possibility of the passage of total repeal legislation either on the state or federal level. The abortion rights movement should press for the passage of the Abortion Rights Act of 1973 which would take the question of abortion out of the state criminal codes altogether.

With the above highlights of still existing problems in mind, it should be clear that the battle women have been fighting to gain full control of their own reproductive lives is far from over. Much still needs to be done to protect and ensure these rights for all women. The abortion movement is and will continue to be challenged on all fronts and at all levels. That challenge must be met with even greater efforts and determination than before.

Bourge Miller has been involved in the abortion movement for a year and a half. She was at one time active with MSWAC, and is vitally concerned with women's right to control their own bodies.

archy we confront in our jobs

ics, Layout and Communications.

the question of who we want BMR

In the summer of 1970, Ana Lou Coelho and her four

children left Oakland, California, to go camping on the
Yuba River outside of Grass Valley in Nevada County,

California.

“It was beautiful and we all loved being on the earth
again,” Ana said. “I asked the children if they'd like to
stay — and they said yes, so after spending most of the
summer there, we moved up permanently in Septem-
ber, 1970. I had wanted to get out of Oakland, and get
the children out of the city — so it seemed like a very
good thing. We were all really happy up there. . .”

One year later — on September 25, 1971, life changed
drastically for Ana and her children — Linda, 11; Sheri,
10; Rhonda, 14; and Ronnie, 7. On that day, Ana was
charged with second degree murder and held without
bail in Nevada County Jail. Her children were sent to
stay with their grandmother. She was charged with
killing a man she didn't know in a barroom brawl. The
man was stabbed to death. Ana had been wearing a
hunting knife in the bar the night of his death.

An all-white Nevada County jury found Ana guilty on
December 10, 1971. Ana has three Apache grand-
parents, and one Chicano grandparent.

We met in mid-February, 1972, 25 days after she had
been sentenced to life and transferred to the California
State Institution for Women at Frontera. She was CIW
number 8811.

Ana, five feet tall, her shiny black hair tied in braids on
each side of her small olive face, looked about 17 years
old instead of 32. She wore a prison uniform covered
by a beige prison jacket about three times too big for
her. Her room, small and bare except for bed, toilet,
sink and desk, was decorated with pictures of her chil-
dren. It was obvious that they were as much the focus
of her life in that small barren room as they had been in
their home on the Yuba River.

“I've never been in jail before and to be plunked down
in prison is so heavy,” she said, her hands shaking as she
fixed coffee for both of us in a small automatic pot.
“At times I get so close to losing my mind; I think I just
can’t take it. I’m here for a crime I didn’t commit. I
guess if I wasn’t innocent it wouldn't be so hard, but I
just can’t accept that I'm really here for something I
didn’t do. All during the trial I was optimistic because
I didn’t see how they could find me guilty of something
I didn’t do. Plus... the D.A. had about 30 witnesses
and they told 30 different stories.

“The only thing they all agree to was that I had a knife

I admitted having. I had my hunting knife strapped on
my side, and somebody took it away from me when a
big fight broke out. It turned into a brawl — like a
free-for-all with 15 or 20 people involved. At this point
I was shoved back up against the jukebox. It was like a
football huddle only everyone was swinging, including
myself. It was during this time the man was stabbed. I
had never even seen him until the pictures of him were
shown at the trial. I didn’t even know anyone had been
stabbed until I heard someone yell, ‘Someone’s been
stabbed.’ The crowd had already dispersed, and we
were standing outside when the police came. I was
standing with this friend and someone told the police
officer, ‘Arrest them two because someone’s been
stabbed and either one of them did it.’ The officer told
me to get in the car, which I did.”

Ana said she was wearing the knife because she was
planning to join her children and another family on a
camping trip when she left the bar.

“I always wore Levis, tee-shirt, and a hunting knife on
these camping trips,” she said. “The knife I used pri-
marily in the preparation of meals, making sandwiches,
cutting watermelon or cantaloupe — just general camping
uses. I used it to help skin a rattlesnake once, but I had
a hard time as the knife wasn’t very sharp.”

During the trial, one pathologist testified that it would
take an incredible amount of strength to inflict the
wound — because it penetrated every muscle and tough
tendon and clipped the man’s backbone. He was
slashed from his chest to his waist. Ana, whose first
arrest came with the death, weighs less than 100
pounds. Testimony was contradictory — and even
Ana’s lawyer, David Kogus of San Francisco, couldn't
believe that the jury found her guilty with such scant
evidence.

Although Ana maintained hope for her freedom to the
very end, she knew the odds were against her, just be-
cause of her ethnic background and the attitudes to-
wards her which came out on the front pages of the
local paper and in the courtroom.

“The witnesses were so hostile. And the jury seemed
disinterested. One lady knitted through the whole trial
and another one addressed Christmas cards. I guess
they were hostile, too. I wasn’t an active member of
the community. We lived three or four blocks out of
town. We had made friends with a family with seven
children and apparently the community didn’t like them
so, they were hostile to me because of our association
with them. I didn’t know how unpopular they were
until the trial. It was also against me that I’d been
divorced six years and I was on AFDC (welfare). All
kinds of negative points. Witnesses said they heard me
arguing and saying things in Mexican or Spanish, but I
can't neither speak Mexican nor Spanish, so whatever I
said was in English! It didn't matter to them that I
had been past president of the PTA in Alameda, or

active with the drug abuse council and the Alameda
City Council. None of these things were brought up in
the trial. They said I was on welfare, but they didn’t
say that I had been working with the social worker and
he was putting me on job training. I wanted clerical or
secretarial work, although I'd like to teach roller-ska-
ting. (Ana took third place in the National Roller
Skating Meet in 1956 in Richmond, Virginia, represent-
ing the Bay Area and California.)

“The jury was unbelievable,” her attorney said.

“They were so hostile to her; it was apparent from the
first. Ana was disliked in the area because she was close
to people in a motorcycle gang who had moved to Grass
Valley and terrorized the people. It's a conservative,
white, older community of people who had moved out
to Grass Valley to escape the cities themselves. I was
used to San Francisco juries, and I didn’t anticipate or
see what a small-time jury would be like. Ana had asked
me to get a change of venue and she was right, I should
have listened to her. I’ve been living with this case now
and it’s really rough. Ana has beautiful children, and
comes from a fine family. I feel so strongly about it I
don’t think I'd go back to Nevada County for another
trial.

Dear Mom,

I hope you can get here for

must be mean to keep

you in peace

Ronnie,

“There were allegedly two eyewitnesses, but they didn’t
seem like much to me. And I don’t think they’re worth
much ...so I would expect that eventually we'll get her
out on appeal. I’m confident we'll get her a new trial.
I just don’t know whether they’ll cut her loose or not. I
don’t know... I can only hope.

“I went to New York to talk to the guy who really did
it. But he’s too scared — he’s on parole — and not will-
ing to confess to anything, let alone open his mouth... 
so that’s not much help.”

“When I first got here,” Ana said, “I didn’t know any-
thing. Like the first day I went back to my room and it
was locked — I went up to the control desk and asked

if I could have a key to my door. She just looked at me
and said, ‘No, we don’t give keys.’ I said, ‘Well, how do
I get in?’ ‘Just tell us and we'll pop your door,’ the
officer said. I was so scared and ignorant of what I
could and couldn't do, I just stayed in my room that
first week and went so close to going out of my mind —
I was dangerously close to it. I knew I couldn’t stay.
But then I found out we could go out in the yard — plus
I found a copy of the rules and read them and knew
more what was going on.

“It's so hard to write to my kids — there’s nothing to
write but bad things. All I can tell them is someday
justice will be done. Ronnie said, ‘Those people must
be mean to keep you there,’ and I just told him, ‘They
can’t help it — they’re doing what the court ordered
them to do. It’s hard for them to understand — I'm
innocent, yet I’m being punished for it. It's hard for
me to understand too — and I guess I never will accept
it. God knows I am innocent — and if I can just main-
tain my sanity, someday justice will be done. It has to
be. I can’t stand not being with my children.”

(This article is excerpted from a book Kitsi Burkhardt
is writing on women in prison, to be published by
Doubleday in March, 1973. Permission to reprint
should be obtained from the author. We are grateful
to Off Our Backs, a paper for women’s liberation, for
calling Ana Coelho’s situation to our attention.)

DIALECTIC OF SEX, by  
Shulamith Firestone  

Shulamith Firestone was born  
in Ottawa, Canada. She atten-  
ded several universities in  
the U.S. and earned a Bachelor  
of Fine Arts in Painting.  

She is presently editor of  
"Notes," a journal of radical  
feminism.  

In Dialectic of Sex, Ms.  
Firestone presents a clear  
idea of the women's movement.  
She replaces the myths and  
fears surrounding feminism with  
reasoning and understanding.  
She brings an awareness of the  
way in which each of us is  
being destroyed by our society.  
Further, she explains how  
women and men can only  
develop half of themselves at  
the expense of the other half.  
The myth has always been that  
the two sexes complement each  
other's abilities and personal-  
ity. But women and men are  
whole complete beings within  
themselves. So what part of  
our roles is a result of  
socializing and what part is  
biological? Or is any of it  
biological? Or is all of it  
socializing?  

The love-myth is destroyed  
in Ms. Firestone's explanation  
of the selfishness involved in  
a relationship...possessiveness,  
envy, jealousy, the obvious  
importance of physical beauty  
(make-up, clothes, hair.) The  
games we play; she bolstering  
his ego, he "protecting" and  
"defending" her, way up there  
on her pedestal; she being  
"delicate" and "feminine;" he  
being “strong" and a "real  
man."  

In relating feminism and  
Freud, Ms. Firestone points  
out Freud's greatest  
failing, that of questioning  
the individual, rather than  
society as a whole as the cause  
for so-called "maladjustment."  
‘Feminism and Freudianism  
arose at about the same period  
of time; but Freud was  
accepted as the "lesser of two  
evils," even though his  
theory is full of contradic-  
tions.  

Shulamith Firestone  
discusses and breaks down the  
entire theory of the family  
structure: father as bread-  
winner, mother as nursemaid  
and somewhat dependent upon  
the father, and "children,"  
hopelessly dependent upon  
mother and father.  

This book is recommended to  
anyone feeling and seeing the  
Oppression of our society,  
whether woman, man, black,  
red, yellow, white.

(CPS) At the end of 1972, suppor-  
ters of the Equal Rights Amendment  
(ERA) felt certain of imminent vic-  
tory. Now, three months later,  
massive anti-Equal Rights Amendment  
forces (Stop the ERA) have organized  
in an effort which puts easy and  
immediate ratification of the 26th  
Amendment in serious doubt.  

Early last year, Congress passed  
the Equal Rights Amendment, which  
would outlaw all forms of sex dis-  
crimination that are based on law  
or governmental action. It is nec-  
essary for 38 state legislatures to  
ratify the amendment. To date, 28  
states have ratified the ERA, 11  
have defeated it, leaving 11 states  
undecided. Ten of those 11 states  
must ratify the ERA for it to pass  
this year.  

Opponents of the Equal Rights  
Amendment make two main objections  
to its ratification. They claim  
that passage of the ERA would make  
women eligible for the draft, and  
that it would release men from their  
obligations to support a family.  

Jacqueline G. Gutwillig, chair-  
woman of the Citizen's Advisory  
Council on the Status of Women,  
labelled opponents' arguments irrele-  
vant. She commented that if a  
draft is reactivated, "It would  
only be in a serious national emer-  
gency that would undoubtedly expose  
women to dangers as great as combat--  
and most women would want to defend  
their country in such circumstances."  

As for the opponents' second ar-  
gument, releasing men from financial  
responsibility of their family,  
Gutwillig explained that a court  
never intervenes in a stable family  
situation. Therefore, families  
would continue to make individual  
and personal decisions affecting the  
their lives. In cases of separation  
or divorce, according to Gutwillig,  
the court would take into considera-  
tion the economic situations of both  
husband and wife before granting any  
financial settlements.  

As organized opposition grows  
stronger, supporters of the ERA ner-  
vously turn to a grassroots cam-  
paign in the remaining states in  
order to ensure a ratification, al-  
though undoubtedly a very narrow  
one, of the amendment which will fi-  

nally give women equal rights under  
law.  

Women in Colorado, which has al-  
ready ratified the ERA, who are in-  
terested in supporting its ratifica-  
tion in other states should send do-  
nations to: NOW Emergency Fund,  

P.O. Box 4514, Church Street Station,  
New York, New York 10249.  

Women’s Rights  

Colorado Cases  

JANET BONNEMA vs.  
STATE HIGHWAY DEPT.  

Charge: A job appointment  
was revoked when sex of appli-  
cant was learned, even though  
she was the most qualified appli-  
cant. State Court settlement  
reinstated her at job at  
Straight Creek Tunnel with back  
pay. Federal Court settlement  
awarded her attorney fees,  
$6750 cash settlement, and per-  
mission to do job-related  
duties formerly denied because

attorney for this case, consi-  
dered a landmark in the U.S.

judice against women in mines

placement by a man, even though

cause it was a fairly old case

DEPT. OF JUVENILE PAROLE  

Charge: Discharge on basis

State District Court found in

attempted to reverse decision.

lust, which in women is insatiable...  
Wherefore for the sake of fulfilling  
their lusts they consort with devils.  
It is sufficiently clear that it  
is no matter for wonder that there  
are more women than men found in-  
fected with the heresy of witch-  
craft... And blessed be the Higher  
Who has so far preserved the male

(Malleus Maleficarum)  

It's not nice to fool Mother Nature!

STATES  

I've always thought that the appear-  
ances of W.I.T.C.H. (Women's Inter-  
national Terrorist Conspiracy From  
Hell) was one of the cleverer early  
WLM yippie tactics. And since like  
many of my sisters I'm curious about  
witches, I decided to do a little  
research on the history of women  
and witchcraft for this month's issue  
of Big Mama Rag. One place to start  
such a search is with the late medie-  
val witch craze.  

The European witch craze was start-  
ling in its dimensions. Starting in  
Germany, Italy and other countries  
in the 14th century, it spread to  
France and England in the 16th cen-  
tury. Thousands upon thousands of  
people were killed—usually burned at  
the stake. One writer estimated that  
in certain German cities, there were  
an average of six hundred "witches"  
put to death a year. "Nine hundred  
witches were destroyed in a single  
year in the Wertzberg area, and a  
thousand in and around Como. At  
Toulouse four hundred were put to  
death in a day. In the Bishopric  

of Trier, in 1585, two villages  
were left with only one female in-  
habitant each." And this mass  
hysteria was no delusion of the un-  
educated poor. Belief in witches  
was nearly universal, even among  

the emerging scientific community.  
Most important, it had the active  
support of the all-powerful Church,  

“Christianity or dreams”  

If it is true as some have suggested,  
that witchcraft represented surfac-  
ing of an older pre-Christian cult in  
which women played a major role, you  
would expect the Church to feel very  
threatened by it. Oddly enough the  
Church had through most of its his-  
tory officially considered the tra-  
ditional powers of witches—casting  

spells, turning themselves into ani-  
mals and so on—as the products of  
insanity or dreams. What changed  
the Church's mind is not clear. We  
do know that by the end of the 14th  
century pressures that would lead  

to the Reformation were mounting.  
For whatever reason, by the 15th  

century, the Church had decided that  

witchcraft was a threat to orthodoxy.  
By the end of the century the Pope,  
Innocent VIII, was issuing papal  
bulls, empowering his representa-  
tives to try witches.  

One of his representatives, Jacob  
Springer and Heinrich Kramer, sent  
to try witches in Germany, produced  
Christendom's guide on the theory  
and identification of witches, Mal-  
leus Maleficarum or Hammer of Witches.  
As you can see from the passage  
quoted at the beginning of this  
article, these two were obsessed with  
the witch's sexuality, especially  
the sexuality of the female witches.  
(Was celibacy getting to them?)  

The book also noted witches’ healing  
powers and warned of their knowledge  
of contraception and abortion proce-  
dures.  

Changing men into beasts  
"Now there are, as it is said in the  
Papal Bull, seven methods by which  
they infect with witchcraft the  
venereal act and the conception of  
the womb: First, by inclining the  
minds of men to inordinate passion;  
second, by obstructing their genera-  
tive force; third, by removing the  
members accommodated to that act;  
fourth, by changing men into beasts  
by their magic act; fifth, by de-  
stroying the generative force in  
women; sixth, by procuring abortion;  
seventh, by offering children to the  
devils, besides other animals and  
the fruits of the earth with which  
they work harm."  

Terrifying as these powers were, I  
wonder if women saw all of them in  
quite the same evil light that the  
two priests did.  

The persecution of witches in this  
country has a short and a somewhat  
less sordid history. The first  

witchcraft trial in the English colo-  

nies for which we have records, oc-  
curred in Windsor, Connecticut in  
1647. During the next fifty years,  
there were a total of about one  
hundred cases out of which thirty-  
eight persons were convicted and  
hanged (not burned). The notorious  
Salem witch trials were different  
from the earlier ones. Occurring at  
the tail end of the witch craze in  
Europe they were examples not of  
isolated accusations and trials, but  
of mass hysteria in a backwater New  
England village. Early in 1692, a  
group of girls age 9 through 19  
accused a woman slave, Tituba, and  
two elderly poor women of having  
bewitched them, causing them to jerk  
and shriek. The slave was beaten in-  
to confession by her master. Those  
accused began to implicate others  
and confess to broomstick rides,  
witches' sabbaths, copulation with  
the devil and so on. By May when  
the governor arrived from Boston,  
several dozen accused witches were  
awaiting trial. The governor ap-  

pointed a special court of laymen  
to try the accused.  

‘Overwhelming’ evidence  

Records still exist of those trials.  
Take for example, the trial of one  
Susanna Martin. The evidence against  
Mistress Martin was overwhelming.  

Her fellow townsman, Bernard Eache,  
testified that:  

"...being in bed on a Lord's Day  
night, he heard a scrambling at the  
window, whereat he then saw Susan-  
na Martin come in and jump down upon  
the floor. She took hold of this  
deponent's feet, and drawing his body  
up unto a heap, she lay upon him  
near two hours; in all which time he  
could neither speak nor stir."  

Another Salem resident, Robert Dow-  
ner, accused Mistress Martin of witch-  
craft and the following night:  

“as he lay in his bed, there came  
in at the window the likeness of a  
cat, which flew upon him, took  
fast hold of his throat, lay on him  
a considerable while, and almost  
killed him."  

And one William Brown further testi-  
fied that Susanna often appeared  
to his wife:  

"giving her no little trouble;  
and when she did come, she was  
visited with birds that sorely  
pecked and pricked her; and some-  
times a bunch, like a pullet's egg,  
would rise in her throat, ready to  
choke her..."  

Traditional witch's powers with sexu-  
al overtones. Susanna, as you might  
expect, was found guilty and exe-  
cuted. When the Salem court ad-  
journed, some nineteen or twenty  
persons, mostly women, and two dogs,  
sex unclear, had been hanged.  

Why always women?  

The events in Salem Village have been  
attributed to any number of causes,  
"exhibitionism natural to young  
girls," the evils of Puritanism,  
the sociology of a small back-  
water village. But the question

craft crazes, but why, throughout  
Western history, have the accused  
usually been women?

back, long before the Christian era.  
It is as if men have always seen  
women as a split person. From the  
earliest pre-history when the ferti-  
lity goddess was divided into the  
beneficent great mother and the

dom.

ity of women dealing with

WOMEN'S RIGHTS BY LAW —— the 19th step forward?

The law functions as the skeleton  
of our society. It holds deeply  
rooted mores, prejudices and beliefs  
in a coherent structure.

A revision of the law almost nev-  
er precedes a recognized and strong  
movement manifesting a change in our  
system of values, but rather follows  
such a change. Even when altera-  
tions are made in the laws, if the  
social movement that caused the  
change was not broad enough or deep  
enough, then the new or amended law  
will have little effect. It will be  
ignored or interpreted so strictly  
by the courts that its range becomes  
extremely narrow and thus its power  
negligible.

Two examples of the above would  
be the Fourteenth Amendment of the  
United States Constitution (Equal  
Rights Under the Law) and the Nine-  
teenth Amendment (Giving Women the  
Right To Vote).

The Fourteenth Amendment was  
passed shortly after the Civil War  
and for many years was interpreted  
to apply only to discrimination in-  
volving Blacks. It took decades be-  
fore the U.S. Courts began applying  
the 14th Amendment to any irrational  
discrimination against recognizable  
groups within our society.

After the passage of the 19th  
Amendment giving women the right to  
vote, the women's suffrage movement  
seemed to slowly come to a standstill  
for many years. Women did indeed  
vote, but as far as the law was con-  
cerned, that was about the only  
change for women.

The Justices sitting on our high-  
est Court through their decisions  
over the past century reflected what  
was the predominant attitude in our  
society about a "woman's place."

Around 1872, Mrs. Bradwell wanted  
to become a lawyer in the State of  
Illinois. The Illinois Bar Associa-  
tion said no. She appealed and the  
case was decided by the United States  
Supreme Court. The Supreme Court up-  
held the Illinois Bar Association.  
The Court said through Justice Bradley:

"Man is, or should be, woman's  
protector and defender. The natu-  
ral and proper timidity and deli-  
cacy which belongs to the female  
sex evidently unfits it for many  
of the occupations of civil life.

The constitution of the family or-  
ganizations, which is founded in  
the divine ordinance, as well as  
in the nature of things, indicates  
the domestic sphere as that which  
properly belongs to the domain and  
functions of womanhood. The har-  
mony, not to say identity, of in-  
terests and views, which belong,  
or should belong, to the family  
institution is repugnant to the  
idea of a woman adopting a dis-  
tinct and independent career from  
that of her husband."

The actual legal basis for the  
decision was based upon a married wo-  
man's inability to make and enforce  
contracts. Only her husband could do  
that. Therefore the court was wor-  
ried about how a married woman could  
effectively contract with and for her  
clients.

The Court went on to say: "The  
paramount destiny and mission of  
woman are to fulfill the noble be-  
nign offices of wife and mother.  
This is the law of the Creator."

It is ironic to discover how the  
protective laws for women were ap-  
proved by the U.S. Supreme Court.  
The approval of such laws was con-  
sidered to be a step in the right di-  
rection for the labor movement.

In 1905 New York had in effect a  
law applying to both men and women  
which stated that no worker could be  
required to work in a bakery more  
than 60 hours a week or 10 a day.  
That law was challenged and struck  
down by the U.S. Supreme Court. The  
law in so far as it concerned men was  
unconstitutional as a violation of  
the right to contract and due process.  
Note that the law was unconstitutional  
only as to men. The door was left  
open.

In approximately 1908 the Oregon  
Legislature passed a law limiting the  
hours a woman could work in a factory  
to 10 a day. The law was challenged,  
but the U.S. Supreme Court upheld  
the law and stated in part:

"The two sexes differ in struc-  
ture of body, in the functions to  
be performed by each, in the amount  
of physical strength, in the capa-  
city for long-continued labor, par-  
ticularly when done standing, the  
influence of vigorous health upon  
the future well-being of the race,  
the self-reliance which enables  
one to assert full rights, and in  
the capacity to maintain the  
struggle for subsistence. This  
difference justifies a difference  
in legislation, and upholds that  
which is designed to compensate  
for some of the burdens which rest  
upon her.”

The critical language in this case  
(Muller vs. Oregon) follows:  
"...Though limitations upon per-  
sonal and contractual rights may  
be removed by legislation, there  
is that in her disposition and  
habits of life which will operate  
against a full assertion of those  
rights....Differentiated by these  
matters from the other sex, she is  

by Kathy Bonham

properly placed in a class by her-  
self, and legislation designed for  
her protection may be sustained,  
even when like legislation is not  
necessary for men, and could not  
be sustained."

This language has been used up to  
the present time to justify a legal  
double standard for men and women.  
Thus sex became a valid basis for  
classification and a valid basis for  
differentiation.

Protective laws sprang up in every  
state "protecting" women from long  
hours, from lifting heavy weights and  
from such things as going into mines  
and so forth. In the first case,  
Bradwell vs. Illinois, the Fourteenth  
Amendment equal protection argument  
was not even raised.

The entire concept brought over to  
this country from England of women  
as chattels (personal property) be-  
longing either to their fathers or  
their husbands was enhanced by such  
decisions handed down by our high  
court. Up until the last decade or  
so, women in almost all states suf-  
fered from legal disabilities such as  
the right to contract by herself,  
the right to have certain kinds of em-  
ployment, the right to control her  
property or indeed even to have pro-  
perty, the right to go into business  
on her own, the right to be on a  
jury and on and on.

Women and children and idiots have  
been treated in very much the same  
way in our laws. The basis of the  
theory behind this grouping is that  
women, children and idiots must be  
protected and special attention must  
be paid to them. This attitude has  
brought some curious results.

For instance, many states up until  
a decade ago had special sentencing  
arrangements for women. The laws of  
a particular state would set forth  
the minimum and maximum sentence that  
one could be given for being convicted  
of a particular crime. An example  
would be 4 to 15 years.

All of this was done in the name  
of helping the woman, just as many  
of our laws regarding the insane and  
juveniles are made for protection  
but more often than not result in  
far greater harshness than a "normal"  
man would receive from a standard  
sentence for the same or a worse  
crime.

Most of these kinds of laws re-  
garding sentencing of women have  
been repealed or held unconstitution-  
al in recent years. The 14th Amend-  
ment has been the primary vehicle  
for such declaration of unconstitu-  
tionality.

The part the law has played in  
maintaining much of the myth and  
prejudice about women is considerable,  
complex and revealing. The above  
barely touches upon the meat of the  
subject.

How our society finally reached  
the point of passing an Equal Rights  
Amendment for women and just what if  
anything that Amendment will do is  
an interesting investigation and a  
lengthy one.

Kathy Bonham is a lawyer who has  
been practicing law in Denver for  
over a year.

WOMEN'S POLITICAL CAUCUS

The Colorado Women's Political Caucus (CWPC) meetings Sat. March 10 at Temple Square seemed on the surface to be a dull affair. Not only was the meeting strong-armed by a presiding officer and a parliamentarian, but the agenda included such exhilarating topics as the budget and by-laws!

But tucked away in the back pages of CWPC's rulebook are some exciting concepts, to-wit:

1. U.S. women have held more than 70% of the delegate positions at the precinct convention level and less than 4% at the state level, which means that women have had the deciding vote in electing men to represent them. A little political consciousness raising is in order here!

2. Women are beginning to recognize themselves as a voting block transcending traditional party affiliations. To quote Republican State Rep. Carol Tempest, the same people voted for her that voted for Democrat Pat Schroeder.

3. To organize a self-conscious women's vote is to give women power. It's a lot easier to negotiate when you can say with credibility, "There are 40,000 voting women waiting to hear your decision.”

A conversation with outgoing CWPC chairperson Mary Ellen Gallagher revealed that CWPC is just getting firmly on its feet as a non-partisan women's caucus. Last year during election efforts, separate caucuses formed inside each party, with the Democrats' CWPC emerging as the strongest. (50% of Colorado’s delegates to the national Democratic convention were women.)

When the National Women's Political Caucus (NWPC) convened in Houston last February, two groups attended from Colorado, the Democratic caucus and the non-partisan caucus. Since that time, much has gone on behind the scenes to resolve the problem of party co-existence within the Colorado caucus to make it an organization that any woman - Republican, Democrat, or Independent -- would feel comfortable in. Some of the tedium evident at Saturday's meeting was directly related to such efforts, Ms. Gallagher said.

In reference to NWPC's convention, she cited as "frustrating” the fact that there was “absolutely no parliamentary procedure." The assembly spent four hours trying to resolve a very minor detail, she said. However, out of the chaos, women gained new confidence in themselves. "You'd hear someone speaking who didn't know a whole lot more than you did, and the next thing you knew, you'd be up there yourself having your say before the crowd."

The "superstars" stayed in the background: women like Shirley Chisholm, Bella Abzug, and Gloria Steinem made themselves available to the delegates, sharing their expertise, but they were deliberately low-key so that new leaders would emerge.

One inspiring element of the NWPC convention that Ms. Gallagher "didn't anticipate" was a "sense of history," of being a part of a movement, not only in rhetoric but in actual, solid, practical fact.

Bringing that inspiration to the grassroots level involves a lot of hard work. Current priorities include: (1) expanding membership to establish a true power block; (2) getting women elected to all levels in government ("If you want girls in shop classes in high school, you'll get funds for the equipment a lot faster if there are women on the school board."); and possibly (3) researching the effect on women of negative political maneuvers like Nixon's welfare cutbacks.

Ms. Gallagher, who is more comfortable herself outside the present political system, nevertheless believes that an organized women's effort utilizing present party structures is needed at this time. She pointed out that, although some feminists are “liberating themselves" by creating autonomous lifestyles outside the system, there are many women oriented to traditional political structures for whom a women's caucus provides a first rallying point for feminist issues. Moreover, women of all political leanings -- inside and outside the system -- who realize the need to join with other women in a common effort look to the caucus for the necessary structure to make this realization a powerful reality.

A few facts: President of NWPC is Frances (Sissy) Farenthold of Texas. Newly elected CWPC officers are President Marye Scharf, Vice President Estelle Firkany, Secretary Marilynne Siggerstaff, and Treasurer Bonnie Andrikopoulos. CWPC's Board of Directors: Jean Bain, Mary Ellen Gallagher, Karen Paget, Lydia Pena, Cynthia Small, and Rory Zahorek. Membership mailing address: 560 Clarkson.

your own courses, securely  
tied to your egos as you  
cleave between the Scylla of  
irrelevance and the Charybdis  
of blank failure.

Are you not trying mainly  
to build up your own idea of  
your self-worth? May I suggest  
that this is a valid goal, and  
that the B.M.R. adopt an  
unwritten editorial policy of  
building the ego of many  
women up to the point equal to  
their abilities, a policy of  
encouraging women to reach  
their full potential in the  
intellectual and financial and  
artistic terms dictated by our  
society? Wouldn't this be a  
more positive approach than the  
somewhat narcissistic policies  
you advocate? (After all just  
how many women or men feel  
obliged "to write about their  
feelings, ideas?")

Such a policy as I suggest  
though would require discipline.  
You could not go spouting off  
about Pat Schroeder. Your  
interviewers would have to  
strive to ask her questions  
which bring out her sterling  
qualities, to draw out her  
motivations so other women  
might identify similar forces  

in themselves.

David and I certainly shared

Fights, misunderstanding  
and anger began, and was I  
alone. Here I was with what  
most people considered a  
model husband, and I had always  
felt lucky (read: superior).  
I had had talks the previous  
spring with a woman who, with  
her husband, had explicitly  
delegated jobs. I had felt  
David and I had a "greater"  
mutual understanding and we  
didn't need such artificial job  
outlines. Our commitment to  
equality was enough. We  

started to assign specific jobs.

one who always thought of what  
to do. We tried to change

well and so unfortunately, had  
David. Our struggles were  
those that many sisters have  
gone through about housework,  
but complicated by Amanda's  
total presence and dependence.  
Our struggles were really  
hard. They were our first ones  
specifically around women's  
issues, and a few words of  
awareness do not break up old  
patterns. The change is  
painful and scary when you feel  
like a fanatic unappreciative  
bitch - but compared to anyone  

else's situation I was lucky.  

My angry feelings turned  

inward, repressed and sometimes

nobody else. I didn't want to  
admit failure. "If it's so bad,  
why did you have a baby in the

others would say to me.

ACTUAL SPEECH OF WOMEN'S  

I am not a liberated woman.  
I do not know of one woman in  
this world who is liberated -  
being female we are all equally  
subject to the same inherent  
evils in our everyday living  
situations. To believe that  
the freedom of women focuses on  
individual solutions to “our  
problems" is just another rusty  
door which should've been  
kicked off its hinges by all  

of us years ago.  

When I walk down the street  
I am just as likely to be  
leered at, whistled at, or  
made the butt of some insensi-  
tive joke as my mother is, or  
my next-door neighbor, or the  
woman who works as a doctor  
or the one who performs  
janitorial services. When any  
woman applies for a job which  
has previously been held mainly  
by men, she is just as likely  
to be hassled about it whether  
she identifies with Margaret  
Mitchell or with Kate Millett.  
There are no individually free  
fish in an aquarium.  

No one today would think of  
telling a black person that her  
or his discrimination is an  
individual dilemma. "Pull  
yourself up by your bootstraps"  
has pretty much been buried  
under the pile of old books  

where it belonged in the first  

place. It is also generally  
acknowledged that racism is  

the direct result of someone's  
huge obnoxious thumb being  
pressed down upon someone  
else's vulnerable if unwill-  
ing head.  

Yet as women we still fall  
into the trap that we are our  
own thumb-pressers, that the  
snapping of the strings  
which bind us can be accompli-  
shed with thousands of personal-  
ly monogrammed scissors,  
that the problem is ultimately  
one of "human liberation" (and  
look who's already ahead by  
the very nature of the word).  

The liberation of women  
does not mean exchanging  
female stereotypes for male  
stereotypes. We should not  
wish to adopt either the  
feminine or the masculine roles  
as they are presently conceived -  
Migrant Mary  
Homemaker vs. Mr. Ulcerated  

Maybe I Can Answer  

Mariame Waters  

Walter Wall Street. Further-  
more, the liberation of women  
does not mean that our publi-  
cations are similar to the  
male-dominated women's  
magazines - e.g. Family  
Runaround, Redneck Book,  
Cashmopolitan, Vague, Women‘s  
Daydreams, etc. Feminist  
publications do not seek to  
make "women's place" more  
comfortable and easy (e.g.  
how to scrub the floor in 5  
minutes instead of 25) but  
rather to question and explore  
the kinds of problems which  
affect all of us as women.  
Pointing the finger  
where it rightfully belongs is  
an extremely necessary first  
step for any second-class  
individual or group. The  
black person who was denied the  
bank presidency because of  
race is not individually  
responsible for that denial.  
The woman who was molested by  
her father as a child is not  
personally accountable for the  
confused way she may always  
view sexuality because of that  
molestation. The feminist who  
sees that she lives in a  
society so lop-sidedly in  
favor of the other sex that she  
is always looking up from the  
bottom of the see-saw must  
justifiably be angry with whom  
she sees sitting at the top.  
Nevertheless, this revela-  
tion is only a first step and  
we as women must constantly  
work together to carry over  

the realities of our political  
sexual, and economic (etc.)  

discoveries (and what are  
"human issues" composed of  
after all?) into our everyday  
living situations. Only  

then can we begin to make a  
revolution with our lives.  

But by continuing to believe  
that every woman is personally  
accountable for the less-than-  
someone role that's always  
been thrust upon us we may all  
end up in the playground -  
together but alone at the  
bottom of our respective see-  
saws. There is a moral to be  
drawn here and while it may not  
be quite so old and venerated  
as some it is certainly as  
worthy. It begins, "United  

we stand..."

Motherhood continued here. The usual household tasks  

were now shared by five of us.  
‘How could I complain that David  

didn't read the childcare  
books? I remember pressuring  
him to read pages so and so,  
and he would, eventually.  
After all, he was working hard  
in school and I had none of  
those pressing commitments.  

(I was registered, but not a  
student in practice.)  

During Amanda's first four  
months I was involved with  
the Woman's Caucus of my  
graduate program. I had a  
dim realization that that con-  
tact was very important for my  
sanity. It was my only con-  
tact outside of my world of  
Amanda, David and the house.  
Winter quarter began and I  
took some classes. I clung to  
that identity and ego-tripped on  
the fact I technically never  
dropped out of school.  

I remember tripping on how  
atypical (read: superior) I  
was. A lot of my words to  
other people, especially women's  
liberation women, were partially  
to impress. I bragged about  
my negative fantasies of  
killing Amanda and didn't let  
myself feel many positive or  
"typical" ones. I dug acting  
cool and indifferent - being  
a liberated mother. I dug  
nursing Amanda so casually and  
successfully. At the time I  
wasn't conscious of bragging.  

I did have fantasies of escape  
from this drama, of feeling it  
was all a temporary game.  

After all, we hadn't established  
any mutual love relationship.  

I knew it didn’t matter to  
Amanda who was holding her, but  
she did prefer my lactating  
breasts to the bottle. As we  
got into a routine, David and I  
could talk and reflect, as op-  

posed to react, more. I  

resented doing more than my  
exact time allotted share of  
baby care and kept keen watch  
on the division of labor.  

When I wrote some papers for  
school and David seemed willing  
to do more than his share, I  
was amazed and guilty because  
I knew I wasn't willing to  

do the same for him. God, I  
thought I was selfish, but I  
kept my principles because I  
felt a vague, unspoken support  
from some women in my life.  

I was angry and jealous  
of David. He not only had  
the rewards of parenthood, he  
had work he could relate to.  
One reason I nursed as long as  
I did was to keep myself as  
Amanda's most special person.  
It was also difficult to  
share the one area of compe-  
tence I felt I had. Once  
Amanda fell off the bed while  
David was in the room with her.  
One of my gut reactions was it  
wouldn't have happened if I  
had been there. I rushed in  
when David called for me and  
silently felt, I can comfort  
her better than anyone.  

After all, if she prefers  
David, what else do I have?  

I felt very rigid about  
equalization of Amanda's respon-  
sibilities. Because I didn't  
have anything else satisfying  
of my own, and because of a  
guilt about what kind of mother  
I am, I'd slip into doing more  
than my share.  

David didn't feel as  
isolated or have the desperate  
desire to talk about everyday,  

issues of baby care. One  
reason he didn't was that being  
a father was another something  
he did, not something he "was."  
Being a mother was who I was.  
Somewhere in me I felt  
unrecognized, David was the  
focus of attention by being  
so nice and so responsible for  
his child. “Oh, Alice, he is  
amazing and you're so lucky  
because most men don't have  
that special feeling and intui-  
tion for babies," said my  
mother and her friends. He  
got the public accolades from  
me and my friends as well, for  
what was expected from me.  
Again I was being defined  
in terms of a man. People  
looked at us and said how  
lucky I was to have David around.  
It still makes me angry when  
I think about it because it's  
still going on.  

David realized that he re-  
lated to a lot of taking care  
of Amanda in terms of a burden.  
I felt the same way. David  
and I are in a world of child-  
less graduate students and I  
was jealous of them and  
embarrassed to say so because  
I would make public my help-  
lessness and sense of failure.  
I feel guilty even in writing  
this today because I am think-  
ing "what does this say about  
my getting into the joys of  
motherhood?" Those moments of  
joy were there, but they were  
never long lasting.  

Somewhere in me I feel  
Amanda is cheated - to have a  
mother who is so totally ambi-  
valent, who finds her boring  
in long stretches of hours,  
who resents her constant deman-  
ding dependence. When I  
viewed her as an object to be  
responsible for, my negative  
feelings and fantasies rushed  
in. When I'm taking care of  
her it’s either her trip or  
ours together. Perhaps I can  
read something light or listen  
to music, but there's no way  
I can be into anything or any-  
body else in a deep way.  

What about any positive  
feelings? Sometimes they come  
out of guilt, when I'm wishing  
I was away from her. It  
seemed like I was always schem-  
ing to get away from her. Then  
I realize she herself is really  
cute and innocent and it's  
not her fault she's on this  
earth. She's just a cute  
Amanda panda hangin’ in. Then  
there are the times that I  
really do want to be with her  
and I get into her babiness -  
her constant changing, explo-  
ration, joy, enthusiasm and  
honesty.  

I do dig her and my love  
grows as she does, but in this  
journal I want to stress the  
difficult aspect. Those  
positive moments for me - the  
energy for them is only freed  
up when I don't objectify  
her as a chore to be endured.  
And I don't have to do that  
when we're together out of  
choice. I imagine she knows  
those times I don’t dig being  
with her. And I do believe  

the liberation of children is  
intimately connected to the  
liberation of women to be our  
own selves.

Which one of these 2 drivers...a painter...a mother of  
2...a legal secretary...a medical student...a welder...  
a draftsperson...an ex-nun...past Treasurer of the National Honor  
Society???
